OptionB: Salmonella typhi/paratyphi commonly causes a cough and constipation. It requires antibiotic therapy so a stool sample would be useful.
OptionC: Salmonella enteridis can cause fatal febrile illness
OptionD: Salmonella typhi/paratyphi does not require antibiotics but salmonella enteritis does
Explanation: B is correct and C is incorrect as Salmonella typhi/paratyphi can cause potentially fatal febrile illness whereas the enteritidis causes an acute illness that does not need antibiotic treatment unless severe bacteraemia.

Question: Which genes undergo mutation in Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colon Cancer (Lynch Syndrome)?
OptionD: RET gene mutations associated with MEN2 neoplasia
Explanation:
A: this mutation causes Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome 

B: mutation on APC causes FAP 

C: correct, this mutation causes Lynch syndrome 

D: this causes Hirschprung's disease

Question: An elderly woman is reported to be unable to dress herself or cook anymore but she appears alert - what term describes this change?
Explanation:
apraxia refers to an inability to do purposeful movements 

ataxia refers to a loss of ability to perform co-ordinated voluntary movements 

agnosia is an inability to recognise familiar objects / sounds / tastes 

aphasia is an inability to understand or to speak properly 

prosopagnosia is an inability to recognise familiar faces

Question: A newly pregnant woman has been previously been prescribed a drug for her seizure management however the GP wants to change this medication as it is known to be teratogenic associated with cleft palate and congenital heart disease. Which medication is this referring to which acts to manage seizures by binding to sodium channels and increasing the refractory period?
Explanation:
a - mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure as it osmotically draws fluid from the oedematous tissue 

b - carbamazepine - reduces the incidence of seizures as it is a GABA receptor agonist 

c - midazolam is a benzodiazepine which increases the GABA suppression of nerve activity 

e- dexamethasone is a glucocorticoid steroid which reduces inflammation to reduced intracranial swelling

Question:
The secondary oocyte begins meiosis 2 but stops at x unless fertilisation takes place 

what is x?
What is the approximate frequency of balanced chromosomal translocations in the general UK population?
What genetic condition is characterised by brushfield spots?
Explanation: Brushfield spots, single palmar crease, congenital malformations, heart malformations and a large tongue are all signs of Down syndrome - trisomy 21 (extra copy of chromosome 21)

Question: What is the best definition of axonotmesis?
OptionC: Loss of entire nerve trunk, no conduction
Explanation:
A- neurapraxia

C- neurotmesis
Tags: Cord Syndromes, Motor Neurons, Neuroanatomy, Case 14

Question: Which list describes the order in which sensations are blocked when using local anaesthetic
OptionA: Sharp pain then cold then warmth then touch then conduction in motor fibres
OptionB: Sharp pain then warmth then cold then conduction in motor fibres
OptionC: Cold then warmth then sharp pain then conduction in motor fibres
OptionD: Conduction in motor fibres then sharp pain then cold then warmth
OptionE: Warmth then sharp pain then conduction in motor fibres then cold
Explanation: Local anaesthetics block pain in a predictable order. First sharp pain sensation is lose, then cold, then warmth, then touch and lastly conduction in motor fibres.
Tags: Motor Neurons, Neuroanatomy, Neurophysiology, Neurosurgery, Case 14

Question:
Which Sunderland classification of nerve injury is described by the following? 

 

- loss of axonal and endoneurial continuity

- perineurium intact 

- no conduction
Explanation: The answer is III, axonotmesis, presence of Tinel's sign. There is Wallerian degeneration and scarring within the endoneurium. Recovery is variable and relates to the amount of scarring in the endoneurium and if the injury involves a pure or mixed fascicle.

Question: Chromosomal abnormalities can be detected using a variety of different techniques. Which of the following techniques can detect single-base changes?
Explanation:
A - karyotyping is able to see changes down to a resolution of about 5,000,000 bases 

B - FISH can detect changes between approximately 10,000 and 10,000 bases 

C - array-CGH down to 10,000 bases 

D - MLPA down to 100

E - allows us to look at the structure of DNA one base at a time, therefore can detect single-base changes in DNA 

 

Chromosomal Abnormalities Lecture - Case 7

Question: Which of the following is not an intermediate intrinsic muscle of the back?
Explanation:
semispinalis is a deep intrinsic back muscle which extends and contralterally rotates the head and vertebral column 

all the intermediate intrinsic muscles can be collectively known as erector spinae which is situated posterolaterally on the spinal column

Question: A medical student is reviewing their notes on the vasculature of the spine. Which of the following is a mistake in terms of segmental arteries and which regions they supply?
OptionA: C7-T1: supplied by costocervical trunk from subclavian artery
OptionC: T2-T9: posterior intercostal artery from subclavian artery
Explanation:
the artery of Adamkiewicz supplies T8 to conus medullaris which is the largest segmental artery (and also from lateral sacral artery) 

C1-C6 is actually supplied by anterior and posterior spinal arteries

Question:
A 60 year old man presents with sudden, severe colicky pain in this right upper quadrant. His skin and the sclera of his eyes also appears slightly yellow. You send him for LFTs which are shown below: 

- Total Bilirubin 107 umo/L 

- Alkaline Phosphatase 480 IU/L

- Aspartate Transaminase 45 IU/L

- Gamma- Glutamyltransferase 145 IU/L

 

Given the information above, what is the most likely cause of his jaundice?
Explanation: The presentation of pain of cockily pain in the right upper quadrant is suggestive of Gallstones. The liver function tests also confirm an obstructive, post hepatic cause of the jaundice. ALP enzyme rises to very high levels when the bile canalicular cells are damaged (as would be the case in cholestasis caused by gallstones). GGT can be raised with actuate alcohol consumption, but alongside the raised ALP results, it further indicates liver damage due to cholestasis (build up in bilirubin damages the hepatocytes).

Question: Physiological anaemia can occur in pregnancy due to the dilutional effect of the increased circulating volume. Between which weeks of pregnancy is haemoglobin expected to be at it's lowest?
Explanation:
Haemoglobin at it's lowest usually between 20-24 weeks gestation, and begins to increase again after 24 weeks gestation. 

Haematology in Pregnancy Lecture

Question: Which levels can we test to look at iron stores in the bone marrow?
Explanation:
Ferritin is an intracellular storage protein, of which a small amount circulates. The bone marrow safely stores iron, and serum ferritin levels reflect iron stores in the bone marrow. Serum ferritin should normally be > 15mcg/L. 

Serum iron levels are not routinely tested because iron levels in the bloodstream can change on a daily basis, whereas ferritin is a more stable marker of your iron stores.

Question: Alice has just found out that she is pregnant and that she is not sure what she is meant to call her baby in scientific terms. She has done a very accurate pregnancy test and knows that she is 12 days pregnant. What is the technical name for her baby at this time, and when what will it be called next in scientific terms?
OptionA: Blastomere, it will then be a foetus
OptionB: Compacted Morula, it will then be a embryo
OptionC: Blastocyst, it will then be an embryo
OptionD: Zygote, it will then be a foetus
Explanation: Currently, at 12 days it is a blastocyst. At around 3 weeks it will then be called an embryo.

Question: If B12 deficiency is suspected in pregnancy, what levels can be measured?
Explanation: Serum B12 levels fall throughout pregnancy and are not an accurate measure of B12 stores, homocysteine levels can be tested if B12 deficiency is suspected in pregnancy, though this is rare if the woman was not deficient at the beginning of her pregnancy as stores last for up to 4 years.

Question: The anatomy of the breast is clinically relevant in terms of understanding the process of lactation for breast-feeding and for the diagnosis and treatment of benign and malignant masses. What is the innervation of the breast?
OptionC: Lateral cutaneous branches of the 4th to 6th intercostal nerves
OptionD: Anterior and lateral cutaneous branches of the 3rd to 6th intercostal nerves
OptionE: Anterior and lateral cutaneous branches of the 4th to 6th intercostal nerves
Explanation: The breast is innervated by the anterior and lateral cutaneous branches of the 4th and 6th intercostal nerves.

Question: Until puberty, the immature breast consists almost entirely of rudimentary lactiferous ducts and no milk producing cells. Which hormone stimulates ductal elongation and bifurcation?
Explanation: Oestrogen stimulates ductal elongation and bifurcation.

Question: Which hormone stimulates the formation of spherical masses of epithelial cells (immature alveoli) at the end of the lactiferous ducts in the breast?
Explanation: Progesterone stimulates the formation of spherical masses of epithelial cells at the end of each duct, while oestrogen stimulates ductal elongation and bifurcation.

Question: What does pancytopenia mean?
Explanation: Pancytopenia - means low levels of RBC, WBC and Platelets - this can be due to malignancy infiltrating the bone marrow

Question:
A patient presenting with jaundice is concerned that they have hepatitis. You perform a blood test to confirm or rule out a diagnosis of hepatitis and the results are as follows:

 

HBsAg - negative 

Anti-HBs - positive

HBeAg - negative 

Anti-HBe - negative 

Anti-HBc - negative 

Anti-HBc IgM - negative 

 

These results are consistent with:
Explanation:
The only positive value in hepatitis B vaccination is the anti-HBs. If Hx of HepB, anti-HBe and anti-HBc would also be +. In acute hepB, HBsAg, HBeAg, antiHBc and Anti-HbC IgM would be +. In chronic persistent, HBsAg would be +, as well as anti-HBe and anti-HBc. 

 

AntiHBs would be negative in acute hep B, and chronic active/persistent hepB.

Question: A patient has sustained the following injury to their nerve cells - loss of axonal continuity but the endoneurium remains intact - which type of nerve injury is this according to the Sutherland classification?
Explanation:
Axonotmesis - grade II where there is a damaged axon but with an intact endoneurium 

Grade I has spontaneous regeneration and there is focal myelination damage - neurapraxia 

Grade III is a damaged axon, endoneurium but the perineurium is in tact 

Grade IV there is a damaged axon, endoneurium, perineurium but the epineurium is in tact 

Grade V is a complete nerve transection - neurotmesis where there is a complete conduction block proximally and distally

Question: Pattern recognition receptors on our cell membranes & in endosomal compartments in our cells recognise pathogens and trigger an immune response. A genetic defect in which of the following toll-like receptors is associated with recurrent herpes simplex encephalitis?
Explanation: recurrent herpres simplex encephalitis associated with genetic defects in the TLR-3 signalling pathway.

Question: Which cell is responsible for producing large amount of interferon alpha and beta in the innate immune response?
Explanation: Plasmacytoid dendritic cell produces massive amounts of interferon alpha and beta ad expresses large amounts of TLR 7 and TLR9.

Question: Which age range is it easier to identify a tumour shadow in the breast?
Explanation: As a woman ages, the glandular elements of the breast are lost and it becomes less dense on a mammogram - therefore the shadow of a breast tumour is more easily visible

Question: What is not anatomically identifiable in the breast?
Explanation: Lactiferous ducts draining into lactiferous sinuses is incorrect, lactiferous sinuses are not anatomically identifiable

Question:
Pamela, a 31 year old woman, is rushed into the A and E. Her breathing is slow and shallow, and you notice that her lips and the tips of her fingernails are blue. Her partner informs you that he found her on the floor of the bathroom with a box of codeine. You order an urgent arterial blood gas, the results of which are shown below: 

 

pH: 7.20 

pC02: 65mmHg

pO2: 58 mmHg 

Hc03: 21 mmol/L 

 

What is the best interpretation of these results?
Explanation:
Interpreation of results 

 

Step one- is there an acidosis or alkalosis? 

If the pH is 7.45 or above, an alkalosis - respiritory, metabolic or both is present. Similarly, a pH of less than 7.35 is indicative of an acidosis. In this case, the pH is 7.20, therefore an acidosis is present 

 

Step two- is the primary disorder respiritory or metabolic in origin? 

 

Examine the Pco2 in relation to the pH. An abnormal P co 2 is greater than 45 mm Hg or less than 35 mm Hg. If the pH value moves in the appropriate direction of the P co 2 (i.e., increased pH with decreased P co 2 or decreased pH with increased P co 2 ), a respiratory disorder is the primary disturbance. Similarly, if the pH value does not move in the appropriate direction of the P co 2 , a metabolic disorder is the primary disturbance. In this case, the P cO2 is greater than 45 mmHg (65 mmHg) and the pH moves in the appropriate direction (acidic) and so it is most likely a respiritory disturbance (hypoventilation). This is further supported by the history, which shows signs of respiritory depression after overdosing on codeine. 

 

Step 3- is there any evidence of respiritory or metabolic compensation? 

For a primary respiratory abnormality, calculate the change in pH that would occur if the change in P co 2 were acute (0.08/10 mm Hg change in P co 2 ) or chronic (0.03/10 mm Hg change in P co 2 ). If the increase in Pa co 2 is acute, an increase in Pa co 2 from 40 to 65 mm Hg will result in a decrease in pH that is 

0.08×25/10mmHg=0.20units
or
7.40−0.20=7.20
If the increase in Pa co 2 is chronic, an increase in Pa co 2 from 40 to 65 mm Hg will result in a decrease in pH; that is,

0.03×25/10mmHg=0.075units
or
7.40−0.075=7.32
Therefore in this example, the elevation in Pa co 2 is entirely acute (there is no renal compesnation). Note that if the process had occurred over days, renal compensation would have occurred and the change in pH would have been smaller—that is, closer to 7.32 instead of 7.20.

Note also that renal compensation takes around 48 hours to occur 

 

All information for explanation is taken from: https://www.clinicalkey.com/student/content/book/3-s2.0-B9780323595780000099#section-hl0000533

Question: MOA of Fentanyl?
OptionA: VG NA+ blocked of nociceptors and mechanoreceptors
OptionC: Mu receptor agonist, inhibiting pre synaptic GABA release
OptionE: Delta receptor agonist, blocking presynaptic GABA release
Explanation: It is an opioid, has the same MOA as pethidine however it is given as an IV, infusion or bolus

Question: What is another name for 'breakbone fever'?
Explanation: The symptoms include rashes, headaches and muscle pains

Question:
Miss Lewis presents to the A and E with sudden onset pleuritic chest pain, which has occured at rest. She is breathless and appears very panicked. One of the Junior Doctors examins Miss Lewis and reports that she has diminished breath sounds and is hyperresonant on percussion. You send for an urgent chest Xray which comes back as shown below: 

Given the information above, what is the most likely diagnosis for Miss Lewis?
Explanation:
Chest radiograph showing left pneumothorax with shift of the mediastinum and trachea to the right side (white arrows).
The left lung is not completely collapsed, suggesting the presence of a loculated tension pneumothorax. All of the differentials may present with similar features (SOB, chest pain) however, the chest X ray confirms the presence of pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency and should be suspected when the patient is hemodynamically unstable or with contralateral tracheal and mediastinal deviation and ipsilateral flattening or inversion of the diaphragm on the CXR. 

 

All information and images taken from https://www.clinicalkey.com/student/content/book/3-s2.0-B9780323713337007153#hl0000227

Question: Semi-identical twins are extremely rare. They occur when two sperm fertilise one egg, which divides and makes two babies. By what reaction is polyspermy usually prevented?
Explanation:
Acrosomal reaction allows penetration of the zona pellucida. The acrosome is a unique sperm organelle that contains hydrolytic enzymes that are necessary for the sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida. An increase in intracellular calcium triggers fusion of the outer acrosomal membrane with the sperm cell's plasma membrane, resulting in the exocytosis of most of the acrosomal contents.

 

Capacitation reacion is the maturation of the sperm. it occurs in the female reproductive tract. Sperm are not capable of fertilising the oocyte until they have undergone this functional change 

 

 

 

Cortical reaction. This is the correct answer. Dense granules that lie just beneath the plasma membrane fuse with the oocyte plasma membrane. Exocytosis of these granules release enzymes which act on the glycoproteins of the ZP, causing it to harden. This hardening involves the release of polysaccharides which impede the progression of runners (i.e sperms that are still inside the ZP). The reaction also blocks ZP receptors, preventing further sperm from binding (polyspermy)

 

Cleavage follows almost immediately after the formation of the zygote. it involves repated mitotic divisions which increase the number of cells 

 

Decidualization is the process by which the endometrium prepares for implantation. The endometrium becomes more compact (zona compacta) and separate from the spongy layer (zona spongiosa)

Question: What vaccines are given at 3 years and 4 months?
Explanation: MMR is given at 1 year and again at 3 years and 4 months

Question: What cell causes milk secretion from the breast in response to oxytocin?
Explanation:
Nipple squeeze --> sends a signal to hypothalamus which stimulates oxytocin release from Posterior Pituitary Gland. 

Oxytocin acts on myoepithelial cells in the alveoli and contracts, which causes milk secretion from alveoli towards the nipple.

Question:
A woman, diagnosed with Incontinentia Pigmenti, and her husband have just welcomed their baby boy. Based on your understanding of this condition, what is the most likely genotype of their baby boy? 

 

X- Affected gene 

X- Unaffected gene
Explanation:
IP is an X linked dominant lethal condition. Since the affected male conception dies in the womb, affected males do not survive to the usual birth and are not seen in this situation. An IP-affected female has three possible outcomes at the birth of any pregnancy with equal probability: an unaffected female, an affected female, and an unaffected male. She has given birth to a boy and therefore the correct answer is C. 

 

IP primarily affects the tissues and organs derived from ectoderm or neuroectoderm and represents a type of ectodermal dysplasia.
The swirly pattern that marks out different dermatomes is called blaschkoid pigmentation

Question: Which drug do NICE guidelines recommend in the treatment of treatment-resistant positive symptoms of schizophrenia?
Explanation: Clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic medication is recommended for treatment of positive symptoms in treatment resistant schizophrenia. Atypical antipsychotics are less likely to cause extra-pyramidal side effects. EPS are drug-induced movement disorders, including tremor, Parkinson's-like symptoms and tardive dyskinesia. Atypical anti-psychotics are also known as second-generation anti-psychotics.

Question: Neurotransmitters are chemicals in the brain that act as messengers. Which of the following neurotransmitters has a strong role in pleasure/reward-seeking behaviours, i.e. addiction?
Explanation: Dopamine plays a strong role in pleasure/reward seeking behaviours.

Question: Lexi is 3 weeks pregnant. Her BMI before pregnancy was 28. As hospital settings make her nervous, she has avodied letting the GP know until now. Panicked, she informs the GP that she has been keeping fit and well and that the only medication she has been taking is ramapril for her blood presusre. She asks if she has done any damage by taking this medication, and if she is able to keep up with this medication for the rest of her pregnancy? What is the most likely response of the GP?
OptionA: Taking ACE inhibitors throughout the pregnancy is completely safe and can be continued.
OptionB: Taking ACE inhibitors at any point in the pregnancy causes significant risk to the baby and should be avoided at all costs.
OptionC: There is no good evidence that taking ACE inhibitors during the first trimester will harm a baby in the womb . However, taking ramapril during the second and third trimester is not advisable as it can cause a number of problems with the baby
OptionD: Taking ACE inhibitors in the first trimester is not advisable, as this is the critcal period of organogenesis. However, reintroducing them for the second and third trimester is safe
OptionE: Taking ACE inhibitors in the third trimester is safe but should be avoided in the first and second.
Explanation:
There is no good evidence that taking ACE inhibitors during the first trimester will harm a baby in the womb.  However, Taking ACE inhibitors during the second and third trimesters can cause a number of problems in the baby including:

• Kidney damage which can lead to long-term kidney problems after birth
• Reduced growth of the baby in the womb
• A problem with the newborn baby’s circulation called patent ductus arteriosus. This is caused by a blood vessel staying open after birth (when it should close)
• Reduced levels of amniotic fluid around the baby in the womb (oligohydramnios) which may then lead to:

• Underdevelopment of the baby’s skull bones
• Poor development of the baby’s lungs
• The baby’s bladder being underdeveloped
• The baby’s skull and leg bones being misshapen and the baby having ‘flattened’ facial features as a result of there not being enough amniotic fluid to ‘cushion’ the baby in the womb 

 

for more information: https://www.medicinesinpregnancy.org/Medicine--pregnancy/ACE-Inhibitors/

Question: Psychomotor retardation can occur in major depressive disorder (MDD). It is thought to occur due to reduced activity of which pathway in the brain?
Explanation: Dopamine, as well as playing a role in pleasure/reward, can also be thought of as a movement promoting chemical when it acts on the nigrostriatal pathway. Decreased nigrostriatal pathway activity is associated with psychomotor retardation in MDD>

Question: What is the main risk associated with taking both SSRIs and aspirin?
OptionA: Both block H1 which leads to sedation
OptionC: Postural hypotension due to inhibition of alpha-1 receptors
OptionD: Lowers the seizure threshold so patient more likely to have a fit
OptionE: Too much inhibition of platelet aggregation increasing risk of gastric bleeds
Explanation: Common problem in the elderly. SSRI & aspirin = too much inhibition of platelet aggregation can cause gastric bleeds

Question: Dr Montgomery is looking after a patient, Sarah, who is pregnant and mentions that she is feeling very tired and so an extensive blood count is ordered. When the results come back, the iron levels are slightly low but the main finding is that the platelet count is low too. Dr Montgomery decides to look under the microscope to have a further look and see what is going on with the platelets. She notes that the platelets appear large, few in numbers and appear to be young platelets. No platelet fragments are seen. She goes and finds Dr Grey to test her as to what this might indicate and whether it is an emergency or not. What does Dr. Grey respond?
OptionA: It is likely to be HELLP syndrome and is a medical emergency
OptionB: It is likely to be HUS and is not a medical emergency
OptionC: It is likely to be gestational thrombocytopenia and is not a medical emergency
OptionD: It is likely to be an auto-immune reaction and is an emergency
Explanation:
The fact that there are no platelet fragments found rules out HUS, HELLP and possible auto-immune reactions. It is likely to be gestational thrombocytopenia based on the non-emergency presentation and it is a completely benign condition which will resolve after pregnancy. It is not a medical emergency. 

 

HUS is a medical emergency, so B is wrong in two different ways as well.

Question: Fredrick, 29, and his wife Janet, 30, are trying for a baby. They have a 3 year old daughter Ella, who has Downs syndrome. After genetic testing, it is shown that Fredrick has a robertsonian translocation of chromosome 21. What is the probability that their next baby will have Downs syndrome?
Explanation: After having a baby with down syndrome, the chance of having another baby with downsyndrome is around 1%. However, Fredrick has been identified to have robertsonian 21:21 translocation. This means that both 21 chromosomes have fused together and therefore any zygote will have trisomy 21. The recurrence risk for other translocations depends on the type but it typically 10-15%. For a "normal" mother of 30 who has no previous history of a baby with Downs syndrome, the liklihood of having a baby with Downs syndrome is 0.1%.

Question: Sarah,41, is 15 weeks pregnant. Her BMI is 55 and she has been offered the quadruple test. Her results show low levels of alpha feto-protein and unconjugated oestriol and high levels of beta HCG and inhibin A. What is the best interpretation of these results?
OptionA: Sarahs baby most likely has downs syndrome
OptionB: Screen positive result for neural tube defect
OptionE: Sarahs baby most likely has a neural tube defect
Explanation:
In the quadruple test, the level of four substances (inhibin A, AFP, oestriol and HCG) are measured and compared with the avergae. In pregnancies with Down's syndrome, AFP and uE3 levels tend to be low and hCG and inhibin levels tend to be raised. These are the results that Sarah has recieved-  therefore screen positive for Down syndrome. A screen-positive result means that you are in a higher risk group for
having a baby with Down’s syndrome. As sarah is in this group, she will be offered a diagnostic amniocentesis or possibly a chorionic villus sampling(CVS).

Most women with screen-positive results do not have a pregnancy with Downs syndrome. For example, for every 16 women with screen positive results for Downs syndrome only one will have a pregnancy with Downs syndrome. 

 

What does a screen positive result for open neural tube defects mean?
A screen-positive result means that you are in a group with an increased risk of having a baby with an openneural tube defect. If the result is screen positive, then women will be offered an ultrasound and examaination at 18-22 weeks of pregnancy. The test is considered screen positive if AFP levels are considered to be greater than or equal to two and a half times the normal value.

Question:
Mrs Jones, a 69 year old female, has recently been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation by her local GP and has been referred to a consultant cardiologist. The consultant prescribes her with Flecainide and Rivaroxaban. Mrs Jones (a former scientist) is interested about how Flecainide works. The consultant describes the mechanism of action. 

 

What is the mechanism of action of the drug that Mrs Jones asks about?
OptionA: Activates adenosine receptors which hyper-polarises the AVN reducing nodal excitability
OptionB: Blocks beta-1 adrenoreceptors, reducing automaticity in the nodes
OptionC: Calcium channel blocker that works to slow nodal output
OptionD: Potassium channel blocker; lengthening the refractory period
OptionE: Sodium channel blocker that reduces aberrant electrical excitability
Explanation:
Atrial fibrillation produces aberrant electrical excitability and extinguishes tachyarrhythmias. Flecainide works as a sodium channel blocker (type Ic) in order to reduce this aberrant activity. 

 

Dr Coffey "Drugs used for cardiac arrhythmias" lecture - case 12

Question: What virus would Ribavirin attack against?
Explanation: Hep C

Question: What cytokine is released to promote T-cell proliferation?
Explanation: IL-2

Question:
Maggie is 38 weeks pregnant; her due date is within the next two weeks. This week, she has noticed that she has the urge to urinate even more frequently, telling her husband that she passes small amounts of urine often. She has also noticed that she is able to take deeper breaths.

 

Given this information in the question and the point Maggie is in her pregnancy, what fetal station has her baby most likely entered?
Explanation: Fetal station is the relationship of the presenting part of the baby to the the ischial spines (bony protrusions located in the narrowest part of the pelvis). When the baby's presenting part (usually the head) is level with the ischial spines, the fetal station is zero. Usually about two weeks before delivery, the baby drops into the birth canal. This is called being engaged and at this point, the baby is at station 0. There will be more room for deep breaths and as the bladder is more compressed, urination may become more frequent.

Question:
Paula, a 58 year old female, has started taking a drug prescribed by her local GP. This drug blocks angiotensin-II/ aldosterone-mediated sodium ion re-uptake from the urine in the collecting duct of the kidneys. This drug can produce a specific adverse drug reaction related to its mechanism of action. The potential adverse drug reaction is hyperkalemia. 

 

What drug is most likely being described here?
Explanation:
A) This is a beta-1 adrenoreceptor antagonist 

B) This blocks Na+/K+ ATP'ase which increase Ca2+ concentration in cardiomyocytes leading to positive inotropy 

C) This blocks Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter in the ascending loop of Henle causing potent diuresis 

D) This is a beta-1 adrenoreceptor antagonist 

E) This is correct because it is an ACE-inhibitor (blocks angiotensin-II mediated effects of aldosterone) 

 

More information on this in Case 12 pharmacology lightbulb

Question:
The tennis pitches have just reopened after 4 long months of lockdown. Timmy goes to play a game of tennis and upon his friends first serve, he gets hit in the face with the ball and fractures his frontal and ethmoid bones. 

Which conchae in his nose will this effect?
Explanation:
Superior and middle. These are both part of the ethmoid bone. 

 

The inferior conchae is its own bony structure - it sits on the vertical bony plate known as the nasal septum, separating the nasal cavity into two bilateral and symmetrical anatomical caves.

Question: Elisa has had an extremely emotional abortion. To avoid further distress, the Doctor decides to prescribe a certain agonist to help prevent lactation. Which agonist does she prescribe?
Explanation:
After an abortion or miscarriage, the removal of the placenta results in a massive drop in progesterone. As a result, prolactin is uninhibited and mothers lactate despite not having a baby. To reduce this effect, women can be taped up (to remove autocrine stimulation) and in some cases, are given a dopamine agonist. Dopamine is released from the hypothalamus and acts to inhibit prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary 

 

somatostatin is released by the hypothalamus and has inhibitory action against growth hormone (it is therefore sometimes administered to reduced the effect of acromegaly)

 

Prolactin acts directly on alveolar cells to stimulate the synthesis of all milk components

 

High oestrogen levels stimulates the hypothalamus to release prolactin. It also cause myoepithelial cells to hypertrophy 

 

HPL- is a hormone produced by the placenta, the organ that develops during pregnancy to help feed the growing baby. This hormone breaks down fats from the mother to provide fuel for the the growing baby.

Question:
Jodi comes into A&E with hyperreflexia, dilated pupils and increased bowel sounds.

After taking a history she tells you that she takes SSRIs as she has depression.

What is the likely cause of her symptoms?
Explanation: Serotonin excessive syndrome is made up - serotonin syndrome is an excess of serotonin however this is not the correct name.

Question: Blockage of which ion transporter in the beta cells of the pancreas results in the release of insulin. It is via this mechanism that sulfonylureas act.
Explanation: In the beta cell glucose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate by glucokinase the glucose-6-phosphate then undergoes glycolysis and the Kreb's cycle which produces ATP. ATP (and sulfonylureas) block a K+ channel which leads to a positive charge in the cell. This results in Ca2+ entering the cell which results in the release of insulin from the beta cell.

Question: What is down-regulated during the fed state as a result of insulin?
Explanation:
GLUT 2 transporters are found in beta cells in the pancreas and allow lots of glucose into the cells to stimulate insulin production after a meal

Fatty acid oxidation is down-regulated as the body doesn't require the energy from fats in the fed state

Lipogenesis is up-regulated following the fed state in order to store the glucose taken in

GLUT 4 transporters translocated into muscle and adipose cell membranes as a result of insulin 

Protein synthesis is up-regulated in order to store the excess glucose following a meal

Question: In the fasted state the body mobilises energy stores in order to maintain the level of glucose in the blood. One particular process is up-regulated in order to ensure an energy supply to the brain. The product of this process is acidic. In which cells does this process take place?
Explanation: The process is ketogenesis and this takes place in the liver in the fasted state.

Question: Which glucose transporter is translocated into muscle and adipose cell membranes in order to reduce blood glucose levels following a meal?
Explanation:
GLUT 1 and GLUT 3 are present in nearly all cells and are there for basal uptake.

GLUT 2 is present in the pancreas and takes up glucose to stimulate insulin secretion.

GLUT 4 is correct.

GLUT 5 does fructose uptake in the gut.

Question: What effect does insulin have on potassium?
Explanation:
Insulin stimulates K+ uptake into cells and inhibits the levels of K+ into blood.

This is important as when you are treating a hyperglycaemic event with IV insulin you must also give K+ to prevent hypokalaemia which could lead to a cardiac arrest.

Question:
Jack, a 65 year old male, has been admitted to the Emergency Department. On examination, he presents with a raised jugular venous pressure, a palpable liver edge, marked peripheral oedema and on auscultation, there are crackles at both lung bases. Jack is given a commonly used diuretic which inhibits the Na+/Cl- symporter in the early distal convoluted tubules of his kidney's. This drug can also cause hypokalaemia. 

 

What is the name of the drug that Jack has most likely been prescribed?
Explanation:
A) Thiazide diuretic with MOA described in question 

B) Loop-acting diuretic (inhibits Na+/k+/2Cl- symporter in ascending loop of Henle) 

C) Potassium-sparing diuretic (works by out-competing aldosterone for mineralcorticoid receptor in collecting duct) 

D) Loop-acting diuretic (inhibits Na+/k+/2Cl- symporter in ascending loop of Henle)

E) Potassium-sparing diuretic (works by out-competing aldosterone for mineralcorticoid receptor in collecting duct)

Question:
Rebecca is 35 weeks pregnant. She is 40 years old, diabetic and this is her first baby. Her husband Victor has bought her into A and E as he is concerned. Rebecca has been suffering with right upper quadrant pain, visual disturbances and headaches. The charge nurse takes her blood pressure, takes some bloods and checks her urine. Rebecca's blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg and there is 305 mg of protein in her urine. Her bloods show normal levels of platelets. 4 hours later, her tests are repeated and come back the same.

 

Given the above information, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Pre-eclampsia is a hypertensive disorder that can develop during pregnancy. It usually occurs after 20 weeks of pregnancy and involves new onset hypertension and proteinuria. Rebecca has risk factors in that she is 40 years old and diabetic. The pathophysiology of PE isn't fully understood, but is thought to be due to abbnormal placental development. This consequently leads to endothelial cell dysfunction and damage, causing vasoconstriction. Local areas of vasospasm include the Kidneys: oliguria (low volumes of urine) and proteinuria (sign of glomerular damage), Retina : blurred vision, development of scotoma and Liver: liver injury and swelling. Stretching of the liver capsule typically causes right upper quadrant pain (epigastric pain) which is a cardinal sign of preeclampsia. 

 

In the UK, pre-eclampsia is classified as mild, moderate and severe. Based on Rebecca's presentation of BP > 140/90 mmHg+ proteinuria and symptoms, her pre-eclampsia is classified as severe. 

 

Thrombocytopenia, eclampsia and HELLP syndrome are all maternal complications of pre-eclampsia. Proteinuria and an increased uric acid concentration are useful in diagnosing preeclampsia but not HELLP syndrome.The platelet count is the best indicator of the latter and as Rebecca's platelet count is normal, pre-eclampsia is the more likely diagnosis. 

 

 

 

https://www.aafp.org/afp/1999/0901/p829.html

Question: What are the three broad theories of depression?
Explanation:
these are the three categories, monoamine hypothesis can be to do with dopamine and serotonin however these arent the main three categories:

1. Monoamine - little serotonin and dopamine 

2. Neurogenic - HPA axis, cortisol and chronic stress

3. Inflammatory - high inflammatory cytokines

Question:
What junctions are key in creating the physiological barrier, Blood brain barrier? 

These junctions are between capillary endothelial cells
Explanation:
BBB is a barrier that allows neuronal homestasis, in disease it becomes increasingly permeable allowing pathogens to gain entry. 

I consists of astrocytes and pericytes aswell as SM cells on the out skirts.

Question:
Alfie, an 8-year old, is brought by his parents to A&E due to a fever, headache, runny nose and a cough. The fever has been around for about 4 days and he has mild conjunctivitis too. His temperature is 39.3 degrees C, pulse is 110 bpm, BP is 90/60 mm Hg and his respiratory rate is 38 breaths/min. On examination, the doctor notes some bright red spots with white centres in his mouth (see image below).

 

Based on the most likely diagnosis, what symptoms would you expect Alfie to develop over the next 48 hours?
OptionC: Rash spreading from head to trunk & limbs
OptionD: Erythema and edema of the hands and feet
Explanation:
Alfie has Measles, his mum is a cheeky anti-vaxxer :(

A- Hepatitis

B- Scarlet fever

C- Measles, correct answer (explained below)

D- Kawasaki disease

E- Rubella (german measles)

 

Measles clinical signs & symptoms

Measles has an incubation period of between 7 to 14 days, which is then followed by 3 or 4 days of prodromal symptoms, where the child will have a fever, head cold, cough, and conjunctivitis.

Small pink-white spots are visible on the inner cheek and gums, which are known as Koplik’s spots (seen in the image prompt) ; these are diagnostic for measles.

Roughly 2 days later, a blotchy maculopapular rash appears around the ears before moving to the trunk and limbs.

Question: A midwife performs a vaginal examination for a pregnant woman in labour. The baby is presenting as cephalic.The baby head and neck are slightly extended, with the midwife describing it as "brow presentation".  Which of the following correctly describes the anatomical term and diameter for this position?
Explanation:
Supraoccipitalmental (13.5 cm) is the longest anterior posterior diameter extending from the vertex to the chin. It occurs when the baby's head and neck are poorly flexed (extended) and its the diameter in brow presentation 

 

Submentobregmatic (9.5 cm) extends from the junction of the neck and lower jaw to the center of the anterior fontanel. Its the diameter in face presentation, where the babys head and neck is fully extended. 

 

Suboccipitobregmatic (9.5cm). It extends from the undersurface of the occipital bone at the junction with the neck to the center of the anterior
fontanelle. It’s when the head is well flexed and the baby is in occipital anterior position (vertex presentation)

 

Occipitalfrontal (11cm). Occurs when the head is deflexed (in military position). 

 

Vertex presentation is the ideal position for birth. The baby is fully flexed and cephalic

Question:
When administering an epidural, most clinician use a “loss-of-resistance” technique to identify the epidural space. In this technique, a syringe with a low-resistance plunger is attached to the end of the epidural needle. The clinician attempts to inject air or saline through the needle as it is advanced. The firm ligamentous structures resist this injection. When the tip of the needle enters the epidural space, the air or saline can then be easily injected (the “loss of resistance”), and the clinician stops advancement of the needle.

 

What is the last layer of resistance, described as tough like rubber, the clinician will meet before reaching the epidural space?
Explanation:
For a midline approach to the epidural space, the clinician advances the needle between the spinous processes at the appropriate vertebral level. The needle must pass through five distinct tissue layers: Skin, subcutaneous fat, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and ligamentum flavum

A mnemonic for this is Some Say Spinal Injections Look Easy (skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum and epidural space) 

 

Typical descriptions of the tissue layers (see Figure 1) are that the superspinous ligament is “crunchy”, the interspinous ligament is smooth, and the ligamentum flavum is tough “like tire rubber”

 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2978502/

Question:
Which group of drugs can cause the following side effects:

- inhibition of platelet aggregation (increased risk of gastric bleeds with aspirin/NSAIDs) 

- hyponatraemia 

- risk of serotonin syndrome
Explanation:
A: instead, avoid sympathomimetic and dopaminergic drugs (monoamine overload) and serotonin syndrome.

B: TCAs -  block H1 (sedation- avoid other sedatives so drugs + alcohol), Anti-Ch (dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation- avoid other anti-Ch: antihistamines/antipsychotics), block alpha-1 so can cause postural hypotension so avoid antihypertensives. Arrhythmogenic so avoid other arrhythmogenics or electrolyte disturbing drugs. Lower seizure threshold.

C; incorrect

D: correct

Question: A medical student is reviewing absorption as part of their nutrition revision - which of the following is not absorbed in the duodenum?
Explanation: bile salts are absorbed in the distal ileum (vitamin C and B12 are also absorbed in the ileum)

Question:
Lily, a 23 year old female has been rushed to the ED with the following observations: 

150/90 BP

120 bpm HR 

RR 20 

She is sweating and vomiting as well as appearing agitated and disorientated after collapsing at home. Thankfully her brother found her. She was found on the kitchen floor. The junior doctor, Dr Stevens, on call notes she has fine tremor and her muscles appear rigid and hyperflexed. She has increased bowel sounds and her pupils appear dilated.

 

Upon talking to her brother, the doctor finds she has been prescribed citalopram for depression and she also takes levothyroxine and salbutamol. Her brother mentions had been struggling recently and kept mentioning needing to go to Holland and Barrett because she had heard of some herbal remedies to help her mood.

 

What might Dr Stevens diagnose Lily with and what would be her first line of treatment?
OptionC: Respiratory distress, O2 ventilation support due to hyperventilation
Explanation:
Lily has serotonin syndrome, less likely to be NMS as this is caused by increased D2 dopamine blockade caused by anti-psychotic medication, which Lily does not seem to be taking. Other differentials include dilated pupils, hyperreflexia and increased bowel sounds which are NOT present in NMS. 

 

Hints to her taking St Johns Wort due to the reference to herbal remedies, causing serotonin overload

Question: Changes in right atrial pressure are reflected, and can be observed, in which of the following vessels?
Explanation: Changes in RA pressure are reflected in the internal jugular vein.

Question: The cardiac action potential consists of 5 distinct phases, which involve different currents. Which current maintains a relatively stable resting potential in the ventricles?
Explanation: During phase 4 of the ventricular action potential, IK1 current maintains a relatively stable resting potential.

Question:
Corey is a 16 year old male who has been brought to see his GP by his mum who has become increasingly concerned about his health and behaviour. She tells Dr Littlewood that she has noticed a change in Corey for about 3 months. Corey describes firstly feeling really down for a few weeks, not wanting to go out and see his friends or going to football practice which he normally loves. He gets tearful at this point, before saying he had a complete change after this and felt so happy and able to achieve anything he wanted to. His mother said she heard him talking to himself in his room, and Corey confirmed this saying he could hear people talking about him all the time. 

Corey said this lasted a few weeks before feeling fine again. He describes his current state of mind as feeling "sad and very worried about the future" and describes "not wanting to see anyone or make any plans for anything". 

 

What might Dr Littlewood diagnose Corey with at this point in time, before making a referral?
Explanation:
Likely to diagnose as BPAD I: - 2+ episodes of which one might be manic/hypomanic or mixed, complete recovery between episodes
- BPAD I: mania, can be followed by major depressive episodes but not all the time, psychotic symptoms like delusions or hallucinations occur in up to 75% of manic episodes. Features of mania include elevated, expansive, euphoric mood, irritability and hyperactivity, insomnia, disorganised behaviour, delusions, hallucinations and significant functional impairment.

 

As BPAD II features more recurrent hypomanic episodes without psychotic features.
Tags: Mental Health, Neurophysiology, Neuropsychiatric Drugs, Case 10

Question:
Kelly is a 24 year old female, she rings her GP saying she feels panicky and worried a lot of the time. Upon talking to her, Dr Green finds that she usually feels anxious in large crowds of people, when out shopping or sometimes when she goes out to clubs with friends. She feels embarrassed as she feels she "cant escape" and feels sweaty, shaky and her heart feels like its beating so fast. 

Kelly describes it now being so bad that she avoids going out and prefers to stay inside where its "safe". 

 

What might Dr Green diagnose Kelly with?
Explanation: Likely to be agoraphobia as Kelly's symptoms are associated with places or situations, she avoids them and finds escaping the situation difficult or embarrassing.

Question:
Julie comes into the GP with her 3 year old son. The child has a fasting glucose of greater than 7mmol/l aswell as neurological deficits and deafness.

With this information alone, what type of diabetes would you diagnose her son with?
Explanation: Mitochondrial diabetes, usually presents at a young age with deafness and neurological deficits.

Question: What is the role of the ITO current during the cardiac action potential?
OptionB: Prevents depolarisation going too far past 0 and maximises entry of calcium
OptionE: Drives repolarisation back to the resting potential
Explanation: The ITO potassium current is the transient outward current during phase 1 of the ventricular action potential (AP). The ITO current is active very briefly and is associated with the notch in the AP. It prevents depolarisation from going too far past 0 and maximises the entry of calcium through calcum channels.

Question:
Marigold had brought her daughter Teddy, 18 months old, to the pediatrician. She has been referred as she has not started walking and is instead bum shuffling. The pediatrician takes bloods to check for elevated levels of creatine kinase and performs a neuromuscular assessment. Her creatine Kinase levels come back normal and there is no evidence of hypertonia, or other abnormalities on examination. Teddy appears normal in all other modalities.

 

What is the next  most likely step in Teddy's management made by the pediatrician?
OptionA: Refer to a physiotherapist for core strengthening exercises and to check for subtle abnormalities.
OptionB: Investigate for DMD as Teddy's results are concerning
OptionC: Investigate for Cerebral palsy as Teddy's results are concerning
OptionD: Teddy should not have been referred in the first place as 18 months is not a red flag.
Explanation: Referral is required at 18 months for children who are not walking as this is a red flag. Appropriate investigation include checking creatine kinase (significantly elevated in DMD) and assessment of cerebral palsy with a neuromuscular and other examinations. Both of these appear normal and therefore should not immediately be further investigated. An appropriate next step would be to refer to physiotherapist to check for subtle abnormalities and core strengthening exercises. The limit age of 18 months for walking applied predominantly to children who have had crawling as their early mobility pattern. Children who bottom shuffle or commando crawl tend to walk later than crawlers, so that within those not walking at 18 months of age there will be some children who demonstrate a locomotor variant pattern, with their development still being normal

Question: You are reviewing an ECG of a patient who got brought in to A&E by an ambulance earlier this evening. There is ST elevation in leads II, III and aVF. What is your diagnosis?
OptionD: STEMI due to left marginal branch infarct
OptionE: STEMI due to left main coronary artery infarct
Explanation: Right coronary artery STEMI would show ST elevation in leads II, III and aVF, which corresponds to the inferior territory of the heart, which is supplied by the RCA.

Question: Connexins form connexons to facilitate electronic current spread to adjoining myocytes. Different connexins can form heteromeric channels with different conduction speeds. Which combination of connexins would you expect to find in the AVN?
Explanation: CX30 and CX45 form low conductance channels, which can be found in areas such as the AVN. CX40 and CX43 form high conductance channels which will be seen in areas such as the Purkinje fibres

Question: A patient in your cardiology clinic has an ECG showing P pulmonale. How would this appear on an ECG & what is the cause?
OptionA: Tall pointed P wave, enlarged right atrium
OptionB: Wide and notched P wave, due to left atrial overload
OptionC: Tall pointed P wave, left atrial overload
OptionD: Wide and notched P wave, enlarged right atrium
OptionE: Inverted P wave, enlarged & overloaded right atrium
Explanation: B = P mitrale

Question: During a scientific study, subjects are given activities that would cause their brains to become highly stimulated. What wave pattern would you expect to see on a normal subject's EEG during these periods of high stimulation?
Explanation: Gamma waves are seen on an EEG of a person who's brain is highly stimulated.

Question: Which artery is the most common site for an intracranial aneurysm?
Explanation:
35-40% of intracranial aneurysms happen at the anterior communicating artery. 

 

Rupture of berry aneurysms are associated with subarachnoid haemorrhages and can be treated by inserting a coil.

Question: Which three signs / symptoms make up Cushing's reflex?
Explanation:
Cushing's reflex is made up of hypertension, bradycardia and an irregular respiratory rate. It is a sign of raised intracranial pressure and is a result of compression of the brainstem affecting the cardiovascular and respiratory centres. 

 

Headache, nausea and vomiting is a common triad also seen in raised intracranial pressure but it is not the Cushing's reflex.

Question: Which part of the brain that is responsible for perception, motor control, self awareness and cognition is first visibly affected by a middle cerebral artery stroke because it is supplied by small lenticulostriate arteries that have little anastomotic potential?
Explanation: Lacunar strokes are a result of small clots in lenticulostriate arteries. These are small perforating 'end' vessels that arise from the middle cerebral artery and have little anastomotic potential so are unable to receive collateral supply. They supply the internal capsule and basal ganglia.

Question: Damage to which part of the brain is most likely to cause unconsciousness?
Explanation:
The pons is partially responsible for maintaining consciousness / wakefulness. Damage to the pons e.g. due to a basilar artery infarct or a raised intracranial pressure can lead to unconsciousness.

 

Damage to the thalamus can also result in unconsciousness but this is less likely.

Question: An 88 year old women presents to A&E following a fall at home. She has a reduced GCS, headache and blurred vision. Which type of haemorrhage is she most likely suffering from?
Explanation:
It is most likely to be a subdural haemorrhage because these are commonly seen in the elderly (and alcoholics). This is because they are a result of tearing of the bridging veins and as you age the brain shrinks and starts to pull on the bridging veins more.

 

Subarachnoid haemorrhages aren't associated with trauma - they are spontaneous and most often due to a ruptured aneurysm. 

 

There is no mention of a lucid interval or a fractured skull which are associated with extradural haemorrhages - this are also more commonly associated with younger men.

Question:
Rosie comes to visit the GP with sudden onset double vision. On examination, One of her eyes is pointing inwards. There is no ptosis of the eyelid and swinging light into the unaffected eye does cause consensual constriction of the pupil in the affected eye. Rosie is a type II diabetic and on further questioning by the GP, she reveals that she hasn't been fully compliant with her medication. 

 

The GP suspects diabetic neuropathy. What type of neuropathy is the GP most likely to be suspicious of?
Explanation:
Symmetrical sensory neuropathy most commonly presents with reduced sensation distally. Symptoms include paraesthesiae in the feet (and, rarely, in the hands), pain in the lower limbs (dull, aching and/or lancinating, worse at night, and felt mainly on the anterior aspect of the legs), burning sensations in the soles of the feet, cutaneous hyperaesthesia and, when severe, an abnormal gait (commonly wide-based), often associated with a sense of numbness in the feet

 

Asymmetrical diabetic neuropathy (diabetic amyotrophy) is a condition thought to involve acute infarction of lower motor neurons of the lumbosacral plexus. Signs and symptoms include severe and progressive weakness and wasting of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs, accompanied by severe pain, mainly on the anterior aspect of the leg, as well as paresthesia and 

 

Unlike gradual onset of distal symmetrical or autonomic neuropathies, mononeuropathies are severe and rapid in onset.

The cranial nerves most commonly affected are the 3rd (oculomotor) and 6th (abducens) cranial nerve (resulting in Diplopia, double vision). Rosie presented with double vision and her eye was pointing inwards. This is suggestive of VI nerve palsy as VI nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye. Occulomotor nerve is not involved as there is not pstosis of the eyelid and there is consensual constriction of the pupil when light is shined into the unaffected eye (the occulmotor nerve is responsible for the efferent arm of the papillary reflex to light).

Question:
Bella is an inpatient with anorexia nervosa. On examination, Bella shows evidence of dry skin, bradycardia and hypotension. Her daily bloods have come back and show reduced levels of T3 and T4 and relatively normal - low levels of TSH. 

 

What is the best interpretation of Bella's blood results?
Explanation:
Euythroid sick syndrome can be described as abnormal thyroid symptoms on thyroid function tests that occur in the setting on a non-thyroidal illness. Causes of this include anorexia nervosa, who have notably low T3 levels and low to normal T4 levels due to decreased peripheral conversion. Patients with AN generally have normal to below-normal thyroid-stimulating hormone levels. Overall improvement in thyroid hormone profiles are observed with nutritional rehabilitation. (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3278909/) 

 

Thyroid causes of low TSH and low T3/T4 is referred to as central (secondary) hypothyroidism. This can be case if there is a problem with the pituitary or, theoretically, the hypothalamus.

Question:
There are similarities and differences with the composition of breast milk and formula milk.

 

For example:

Similarity - the two both contain alpha-lactalbumin (although higher amounts are present in breast milk) and casein.

Difference - breast milk contains lactoferrin proteins and lysozyme enzymes, which formula milk does not contain. 

 

Lactoferrin proteins and lysozyme enzymes contribute to the immunological benefits that breast milk provide.

 

Which of the follow is not correct with regards to lactoferrin or lysozyme functions?
OptionA: Lactoferrin helps to maintain normal levels of bifidobacterium.
OptionC: Lactoferrin decreases the production of IL-1, 2, 6 and TNF-alpha.
OptionE: Lysozyme enzymes causes bacterial cell wall lysis.
Explanation:
A - incorrect. This is a function of Caesin or alpha-lactalbumin

The rest are correct. 

 

(Immunological) Functions of lactoferrin:

- Helps with iron chelation (breaks iron down removing excess iron from the body). Iron is essential in pathogen multiplication therefore prevents this

- Blocks absorption/penetration of viruses

- Contributes to intestinal cell repair and growth

- Decreases production of I-L1,2,6 and TNF-a


(Immunological) Functions of Casein

- inhibits adhesion of certain bacteria

- promotes growth of Bifidobacterium (=intestinal and gastric probiotics which help fight harmful bacteria and help with digestion - 'good bacteria')


(Immunological) Function of a-lactalbumin

- promotes growth of Bifidobacterium

 

(Immunological) Function of lysozyme enzymes

- Causes bacterial cell wall lysis

- Increases IgA production

- Contributes to macrophage activation

 

(Case 8 - Anatomy of Breast, Physiology and Immunology of Lactation Lecture)

Question: What does "Steels 1/3 rule" describe in terms of spinal anatomy? The area inside the atlas (C1) is occupied by 1/3...
Explanation: Steels 1/3 rule describes that the area inside the atlas is occupied equally by dens (odontoid process of axis / C2), space and the spinal cord.

Question: Mrs Jones, 36, has been in a RTA and you are concerned about a cervical spine fracture. She has no focal neurology and is 25 weeks pregnant. What would be the most appropriate initial investigation?
Explanation:
A: MRIs are good at visualising soft tissue and for when there is neurological damage. They are also expensive and take a long time. 

B: Bone scans are used to look for metastasis or infection

C: X-rays are good at visualising bones and are fast and cheap so good for trauma situations

D: CTs are also really good at visualising bones but they have more ionising radiation than x-rays and as Mrs Jones is pregnant you would want to avoid this

E: Myelogram are more indicated for nerve / spinal cord pathology

Question:
Stella, a 28 year old female, comes in to see her GP. She is worried because she has been experiencing diarrhoea for over 6 weeks. She has noticed that it contains blood too. She has colicky pain in her abdomen and on examination, the GP notices that Stella has apthous ulceration and abdominal tenderness. 

 

Some investigations are carried out in primary care which indicate that Stella may have Inflammatory Bowel Disease. She is referred to a gastroenterologist to establish whether she has Crohn's or Ulcerative Colitis. A colonoscopy confirms that Stella has Crohn's disease. 

 

What macroscopic changes are seen in the colonoscopy that indicate Crohn's disease?
OptionA:
Raised yellowish, white plaques forming a 'psuedomembrane'

This overlies an erythrematous, oedematous mucosa.
OptionC:
Continuous inflammation of the colon with:

Erythema

Ulceration

Purulent exudates

Granuloma formation
OptionD:
Discontinuous inflammation of the colon with:

ulceration

'cobblestone' appearance

rectal sparing
Explanation:
A is incorrect as it describes the colonoscopy findings for a Clostridium difficile infection. The raised white/yellowish plaques form a 'pseudomembrane'.

 

B is incorrect as it describes the colonoscopy findings for Diverticular disease

 

C is incorrect as it describes the colonoscopy findings for Ulcerative Colitis. Note that the inflammation is continuous, characteristic of UC. Whereas in Crohn's disease the inflammation is patchy and discontinuous. 

 

D correctly describes colonoscopy findings for Crohn's disease. This is due to the discontinuous inflammation which differentiates Crohn's from UC. The rectum is also typically spared in Crohn's disease, although not always. Again, the 'cobblestone apperance' is typical of Crohn's. This is due to ulceration which creates separate islands of mucosa, giving it an appearance reminiscent of cobblestones.

 

E is incorrect as it describes the colonoscopy findings for Familial Adenomatous Polyposis
Tags: Abdomen, Case 15, Colon, Lower GI, IBD

Question: Identify layer of the brain
Identify layer of the brain

What symptom of arrhythmias does this statement describe?

'rhythm that produces no meaningful cardiac output'
Explanation:
All of the answers are viable, however in the statement it said 'NO' meaningful CO - suggesting very low or no CO at all

This would therefore cause sudden cardiac death.

Yes, syncope could be described as reduced CO - however it is reduced not meaningless.

Question: What is another term used to describe heart block?
Explanation:
Heart block is when the impulse between the atria and ventricles is absent or reduced

Heart block can be called AV node disease, hinting at the area of which is affected

Question: What class of antiarrythmic drugs is amiodarone?
Explanation: Amiodarone - can be used to treat VT - class 3 anti arrythmic drug

Question:
What cardiomyopathy has these ECG features:

- elipson wave 

- t wave inversion V1,2,3
Explanation:
Atrioventricular right ventricular cardiomyopathy, usually presents with no symptoms. 

It is characterised by fibro fatty infiltration, ventricular dilation and hyper-trabeculae.

Question:
Erika has been involved in a road traffic accident. The on call Doctor performs an assessment. She finds that Erika is unable to open her eyes to speech and does not respond to any commands. However, when the Doctor presses on her suborbital notch, she moves her hand towards the pain stimulus and opens her eyes. The Doctors asks Erika if she knows what year it is, to which she responds with single words that do not make any sense.

 

What is Erika's GCS?
Explanation:
The GCS is used to classify the severity of the traumatic brain injury. It is the most commonly used method of evaluating consciousness and is based on the best response in three categories:

Eye opening (4)
Verbal Response (5)
Motor Response (6)

 

If a patient receives a score of 8 or less, they are considered to be in a coma. 

 

Eye movements : does the patient open their eyes:

4- spontaneously 

3- to sound 

2- to pain/pressure 

1- not at all 

 

In Erika's case, she does not open her eyes to speech (and therefore not spontaneously either). However, when the Doctor presses on her supraorbital notch, she open her eyes. Therefore, she opens her eyes to pain and would receive a score of 2 

 

Motor response 

6- Obeys a command: if a patient is able to perform a two step action, such as grasping your fingers or sticking out their tongue when being told. 

5- Localizes to pain: Pressing on the supraorbital notch or pinch trapezius for up to 10 seconds. If the patient moves arm or hand above the clavicle towards the stimulus, this is localising to pain.

4- Flex to withdraw from pain: If the arm bends and then moves rapidly away from the stimulus, this is normal flexion 

3- Abnormal flexion: Abnormal flexion is where the elbow bends slowly and the arms come across the body.

2- Extensor response/ Decerebrate: elbows extend (this is a really bad sign)

1- is no response 

 

When the doctor pressed on Erika's supra orbital notch she reached up towards the stimulus. This is localisation towards the pain stimulus, giving her a score of 5 

 

Verbal (5) 

- 5 orientated: patient is able to answer correctly what their name is, what month it is and where they are 

- 4 confused: patient is speaking in phrases or relatively complete sentences 

- 3 words: patient is speaking in single words, gibberish 

- 2 incomprehensible sounds, moans and groans 

1- nill response 

Erika is responding with single words that do not make sense (gibberish). Therefore, she receives a score of 3

 

Erikas overall score is E2V3M5 = 10

Her immediate management should follow and ABCDE approach.

Question: Larry is a 52 year old male who is seeing his GP, Dr Lewis for a routine appointment. Larry mentions briefly that the has decided to stop smoking. Dr Lewis is initially very pleased but upon looking at his notes notices that he is on medication that does not respond well with drastic reductions in usual nicotine levels in the body. What medication might this be?
Explanation: Answer is C: clozapine and olanzapine are associated with toxic effects if there is drastic reductions in smoking, nicotine is an enzyme inhibitor. Dr Green mentions this and offers to help Larry make a gradual plan to stop smoking.

Question:
Missy is a 25 year old female who is taking Clozapine to help treat Schizophrenia. However she has recently mentioned in her outpatient appointment that the medication does not seem to be helping her as she still feels down and fed up, she still doesn't enjoy playing her guitar like she used to and has no motivation to meet up with her friends. 

What medication might her doctor use in combination with Clozapine to help improve Missy's negative symptoms?
Explanation: ARIPIPRAZOLE to reduce weight, lower serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels and can also be used as a combination if there has not been a reduction in positive or negative symptoms for a patient using CLOZAPINE alone. Encourages weight loss but has other side effects including dizziness, drowsiness, nausea, vomiting and blurred vision.

Question: Lionel has been diagnosed with a benign brain tumor for which his doctor has recommended a craniotomy. During this procedure, Lionel will be under general anesthetic. What is one of the effects of the general anesthetic that the anesthetist will need to monitor carefully given Lionel's condition?
Explanation:
Intracranial pressure (ICP) is determined by the volume of brain parenchyma (80%), blood (12%), and CSF (8%) within a rigid cranial vault. Normal ICP ranges from 5-15mmHg. Because the cranial compartment is enclosed by a rigid skull, it has a limited ability to accommodate additional volume (the Monro Kellie Hypothesis). When intracranial contents increase in volume (e.g., secondary to tumor, blood, swelling, hydrocephalus), initially, circulating blood and CSF are displaced to offset the extra volume and ICP remains unchanged. However, beyond a certain threshold, if intracranial contents continue to increase in volume, then ICP will quickly increase as there is diminished compliance in the fixed intracranial vault. This dynamic is critical in surgical patients with already decreased intracranial compliance from space occupying lesions (such as a tumour), who may be extremely sensitive to ICP changes associated with anesthetic effects (e.g., cerebral vasodilation from inhalation anesthetics or vasodilation from periods of hypoventilation/hypercapnia).

 

Hyperventilation is one known method of rapidly decreasing ICP. Cerebral blood flow is largely dependent on PaC02. Hyperventilation causes decreased PaCO2 which subsequently leads to arterial vasoconstriction thus lowering cerebral blood flow (CBF), cerebral blood volume, and ICP

 

His airways remaining patent is a valid concern, however in most procedures this is overcome by the insertion of an Endotracheal tube. 

 

General anesthesia is more frequently associated with hyperglycemia. Volatile anesthetic agents inhibit insulin secretion and increase hepatic glucose production

 

 

https://www.aegisanesthesiapartners.com/anesthesia-library/airway-management-general-anesthesia/

https://www.openanesthesia.org/elevated_icp_hyperventilation/

Question: Claudia is admiring her luscious long hair in the mirror one day. Claudia, ever curious, wonders about the embryological origin of hair. Which of the following is Claudia's hair derived from?
Explanation:
A- incorrect as the endoderm layer of the trilaminar disc gives rise to the epithelia of the body 

 

B- incorrect as the mesoderm layer of the trilaminar disc gives rise to the internal organs, muscles and glands of the body

 

C- correct as the ectoderm layer of the trilaminar disc gives rise to the CNS and the external surfaces of the body eg. skin, hair, nails, lens, inner ear 

 

D- incorrect as syncytiotrophoblasts differentiate from trophoblasts and are not part of the trilaminar disc. Trophoblast cells do not form the embryo but the placenta. 

 

E- incorrect as cytotrophoblasts differentiate from trophoblasts and are not part of the trilaminar disc. Trophoblast cells do not form the embryo but the placenta.

Question: Which of the following best describes the two types of cell present within a blastocyst:
Explanation:
When a morula becomes a blastocyst, blastomeres (morula cells) differentiate into embryoblasts and trophoblasts. 

 

Following implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium, embryoblasts differentiate into epiblast and hypoblast cells (= bilaminar disc).

Meanwhile, trophoblasts differentiate into syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts.

Question: Which type of sleep apnoea is c pap more harmful than good in regards to HF?
Explanation: They can both be distinguished, central has no thoraco abdominal movements whereas obstructive has partial thoraco abdominal movements

Question:
Jackson, 3 years old, has been urgently admitted to hospital. His mother, Eloise,  bought him into the GP earlier in the day with fever, vomiting and neck stiffness. The GP noted that in the supine position with a flexed hip, Jackson was reluctant to extend his knee. When the GP flexed his head, Jackson flexed his knees in response. Jackson's previous medical history shows that he has been treated for a middle ear infection. 

 

At the hospital, an LP is performed. The results are shown below: 

Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most likely causative organisms?
Explanation:
The history of fever, neck stiffness and vomiting is suspicious of meningitis. This is confirmed further by positive Kernig and Brudzinski signs. Kerning sign is noted when a supine patient is reluctant to extend the knee with a flexed hip (as this would increase meningeal tension). The Brudzinski sign occurs when a patient flexes there legs in response to flexion of the head (to reduce menigeal tension). 

 

Jackson's LP results appear turbid and show an elevated opening pressure, markedly increased protein and reduction in glucose. The majority of cells are polymorphs. This is suggestive of a bacterial cause of meningitis. Both Listeria monocytogenes and Streptococcus pneumoniae are bacterial causes. However, Listeria monocytogenes more frequently causes meningitis in children aged under 3 months. Furthermore, Jackson has a past medical history of a middle ear infection. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of meningitis in young children and the elderly; often this meningitis develops from bacteremia or from infection of the sinuses or middle ear. 

 

Cryptococcus neoformans and candida are fungal causes of meningitis. Fever and neck stiffness is a less common presentation in fungal meningitis. 

 

https://www.clinicalkey.com/student/content/book/3-s2.0-B9780702042928000396#hl0000429

She presents with severe abdominal pain and says she has had profuse diarrhoea, which has been very watery and non-stop the whole way back on the plane. She looks extremely pale. Dr Grey decides to send a stool culture to the lab, after running bloods, what would be the next immediate step in management?

Explanation:
Likely Louisa has Cholera, due to the nature of the stools "rice water appearance" and amount of fluid loss. She doesnt appear to be vaccinated and travelled to SE Asia, where there are large outbreaks. She needs urgent fluid resusciation. 

 

Loperamide is prescribed for  used for acute non-infective diarrhoea

Question: What is 'dolls eye' and 'blown pupil' an indication of?
Explanation: dolls eye and blown pupil are optic signs of raised ICP - raised ICP can compress on the optic and surrounding cranial nerves to the eye causing this appearance.

Question: The name given to a diploid cell after fertilisation occurs is called a zygote. What is the name of the process that takes place to form a morula and then blastocyst during days 2-4 of embryonic development?
Explanation:
cleavage = a series of rapid mitotic divisions from the 2 cell stage. The cell does not grow because it abolishes G1 & G2, so they are quite simply replicating DNA. 

 

During cleavage the cells become more compact and space forms in the middle, and this space is called the blastocyst cavity. In making that hollow ball you form two cell populations: 

- the inner cell mass 

- the trophoblast cells
Tags: Development of the normal embryo, embryology, Case 7

Question:
When a foreign pathogen enter the body PAMPs are recognised by PRRs on sentinel cells, e.g., macrophages/dendritic cells. In response to the PAMPs, macrophages produce a variety of cytokines. This is a component of the innate immune response.

 

Which statement below is incorrect regarding the cytokines produced by macrophages during the innate immune response?

 

PAMPs = pathogen associated molecular pattern 

PRR = pathogen recognition receptor
OptionA: IL-6 is a primary endogenous pyrogen. (IL-6 has systemic effects).
OptionB: TNF-alpha increases vascular permeability therefore allows increased entry of immune cells/complement proteins
OptionC: IL-1Beta activates lymphocytes, increases access for effector cells and causes local tissue destruction. (IL-1Beta has systemic effects).
OptionD: CXCL8 is an inflammatory cytokine, which causes lymphocyte activation, endothelial adhesion, induces pyrexia and causes shivering.
OptionE:
IL-12 is a primary inflammatory cytokine, enhances B-cell expression of IFN-gamma during T cell activation and activates NK cells.

 

NK = natural killer
Explanation:
All correct except D

 

A:

IL-6 (inflammatory cytokine) is a primary endogenous pyrogen  that has systemic effects (acts on hypothalamus to raise body temperature, and acts on muscles to increase use of fat and proteins which contributes to the raise in body temp.). It also causes PGE2 production, which leads to innervation of the sympathetic nervous system. This leads to shivering and skin vasoconstriction. 

- IL-1 is also a primary endogenous pyrogen 

 

B:

TNF-alpha = inflammatory cytokine that increases vascular permeability therefore allows increased entry of immune cells/complement proteins. --> Makes blood vessels 'leaky' and causes increased oedema

 

C:

IL-1Beta is also a pyrogen which activates lymphocytes, increases access for effector cells, causes local tissue destruction and fever. (IL-1Beta has systemic effects).

 

D:

CXCL8 is a chemokine/chemotaxis factor - recruits neutrophils + basophils.

The description for D - inflammatory cytokine, which causes lymphocyte activation, endothelial adhesion, induces pyrexia and causes shivering - is a description for the IL-1 primary endogenous pyrogen. 

 

E:

IL-12 is a primary inflammatory cytokine, enhances B-cell expression of IFN-gamma during T cell activation and activates NK cells (which produce IFN-gamma which in turn activates macrophages).

 

Summary:

Inflammatory cytokines - IL-1,6,12, TNF-alpha

Pyrogens - IL-1, IL-6 and IL-1Beta 

 

(Immunological responses to viral infection phase 1 Lecture)

Question: Roger, 24, has been rushed to A and E after being involved in a fight that resulted in him being stabbed. Doctors confirm that he has sustained a spinal hemisection at the level of T12. What examination findings would Roger most likely exhibit?
OptionA: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature below the level of the lesion and contralateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration and proprioception
OptionB: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature below the level of the lesion and ipsilateral loss of discriminative (light) touch, vibration sensation and proprioception
OptionC: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature and contralateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration and propricoception
OptionD: Ipisilateral loss of pain and temperature and contralateral loss of discriminitive touch, vibration and proprioception
OptionE: Biulateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. Bilateral motor paralysis at the level of the lesion and bilateral spastic paesis below the level of injury
Explanation: Brown-Sequard syndrome occurs if the spinal cord has been transected only on one side. The effects of such transection can be predicted from knowledge of the cord fiber tracts . All motor functions are blocked on the side of the transection in all segments below the level of the transection.  Only some of the modalities of sensation are lost on the transected side, and others are lost on the opposite side. The sensations of pain, heat, and cold—sensations served by the spinothalamic pathway—are lost on the opposite side of the body in all dermatomes two to six segments below the level of the transection (as the spinothalamic tract decussates in the spinal cord) By contrast, the sensations that are transmitted only in the dorsal and dorsolateral columns—kinesthetic and position sensations, vibration sensation, discrete localization, and two-point discrimination—are lost on the side of the transection in all dermatomes below the level of the transection (because the DCT decussates in the medulla)  (https://www.clinicalkey.com/student/content/book/3-s2.0-B9780323597128000497#hl0000371)

Explanation: CNS infections plenary
