Question:
Robert,62, presents to the GP with recent back pain which he claims has been waking him in the night. He tells the GP that no matter what he does, whether that be resting or taking Ibuprofen, nothing seems to relieve it. When questioned further, Robert says that he has not noticed any change to his bowel or bladder habits, has not lost sensation and other than his back pain, has not has any difficulty controlling his arms or legs. Looking at Roberts medical history, the GP notices that Robert has been diagnosed with prostate cancer this year, for which he is receiving treatment. 

 

The GP suspects that Robert may have spinal mets. Given the likely diagnosis, what is her most likely course of action?
OptionA: Urgent MRI of the whole spine within 24hrs
OptionB: MRI of the whole spine should be performed within a week of the diagnosis
OptionE: Discharge Robert with stronger pain relief as his presentation is not concerning.
Explanation: MRI is the imaging of choice in patients with suspected MSCC. If suspected MSCC with neurological signs and symptoms, there should be an urgent MRI of the whole spine within 24hrs. If there is no neurology but suspected spine mets (as is the case with Robert who has unremitting back pain, a PMH of prostate cancer but no neurological symptoms as of yet), then an MRI of the whole spine should be performed within a week of the diagnosis. Could consider CT to assess spinal stability. CT also allows staging to be determined (prognosis) and primary site

Question: What is excess excitation after injury exaggerated by?
Explanation: Astrocytes have a range of function, they deactivate glutamate

Question: What is emergency airway access?

Millie has come to the GP with joint pain, legarthy and constipation. The GP runs some tests and it is revealed that Millie has primary hyperparathyroidism. What treatment might Millie be offered for this?
OptionA: prescribed calcitriol with calcium tablets. Careful monitoring is required to optimize the dosages.
OptionB: Surgical removal of the enlarged or overactive parathyroid
Explanation:
https://www.uofmhealth.org/conditions-treatments/ear-nose-throat/thyroid-disorder

 

Hyperparathyroidism occurs when the body continues producing PTH hormones even though calcium levels are higher than normal. For primary and tertiary hyperparathyroidism, surgery is the preferred method of treatment. Surgically removing the enlarged or overactive parathyroid can permanently cure the parathyroid disorder, with minimally invasive techniques available for certain patients.

 

Hypoparathyroidism occurs when the body does not produce enough PTH hormone, causing hypocalcemia. Hypoparathyroidism is usually treated with a special form of vitamin D (calcitriol) and with calcium tablets. Calcitrol is an active form of vitamin D (125 dihydroxycholecalcifero) which increases calcium levels by stimulation osteoclasts, reduces excretion in the kidneys and stimulates active calcium reabsorption in jejenum and duodenum. Careful monitoring is required to optimize the dosages.

 

Hypothyroidism is a disorder caused by an under-active thyroid that may lead to changes in the hair or skin, fatigue and weakness, memory problems, or other issues. Hashimoto’s Thyroiditis, also known as Hashimoto’s disease, is an autoimmune disease that causes the body’s immune system to produce antibodies that attack thyroid tissue and damage the gland, leading to an under-productive thyroid. Hypothyroidism can usually be easily treated with thyroid hormone medicine, typically levothyroxine, which is identical to the main thyroid hormone made by the thyroid gland.

 

Hyperthyroidism is a disorder caused by an overactive thyroid that causes the body to speed up. It can cause weight loss, a faster heartbeat, sweating, or feelings of nervousness. Graves’ Disease is one of the main causes of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disease, more common in women than men, and can be associated with a special type of eye abnormality (Graves’ eye disease). If untreated, hyperthyroidism can lead to serious heart, bone and other problems. The most common treatments for hyperthyroidism are anti-thyroid, such as carbimazole, and radioactive iodine.

Question: For a quick emergency uncomplicated C-section, which method of anaesthesia is most likely to be used?
Explanation:
Spinal (neuraxial analgesia), in dural space, acts very quickly, lasts about 1.5hrs, cannot be topped up and is good for a quick uncomplicated C-section. 

 

Epidural (neuraxial analgesia), in epidural space, lasts longer than spinal but takes about 30-40 mins to work, can be topped up via catheter. 

 

If the C-section is expected to take a long time, a combined spinal-epidural is likely to be used as it will have quick onset (spinal) and be long lasting (epidural).

Question: After fertilisation has occurred, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) acts to maintain the corpus luteum. What secretes hCG?

Question: Glesni is pregnant. Her last menstrual cycle started on the 7th of August and lasted 5 days. What is her due date?
Explanation:
Answer = 14th May

 

To calculate the due date: (first day of last menstrual cycle) - 3months + 7 days 

 

Gestational age is different to embryonic age. Embryonic age is calculated from conception (rather than from the first day of the last menstrual cycle) and therefore is usually 2 weeks shorter than the gestational age.

Question:
Simon, 62, has been referred to the cardiology clinic by his GP. He has a past medical history of type II diabetes and hypertension, both of which he is receiving treatment for. He has been referred as he has been complaining of episodes where he feels as though "his heart is racing in his chest". He also has some shortness of breath. He says that these episodes only last for a few minuets at a time, but he finds them deeply disconcerting. The cardiologist provides Simon with a Holter monitor and asks him to record when every he feels he is having one of his episodes. The cardiologist reviews Simons recordings which are shown below: 

 

Given the likely diagnosis, which of the listed drugs below would be the most inappropriate to prescribe for Simon?
Explanation: Simon has presented with a paroxysmal racing heart and accompanying episodes of shortness of breath. Based on his description, this could be a number of diagnosis (SVT, Atrial fibrillation, Atrial flutter etc). The ECG reading shows no P waves, a seasaw baseline and a REGULAR rythm. In atrial fibrillation, the atria beat irregularly. In atrial flutter, the atria beat regularly, but faster than usual and more often than the ventricles, so you may have four atrial beats to every one ventricular beat. Therefore, Simon has presented with atrial flutter. His management involves rate control over rythm control. Metoprolol and Bisoprolol (beta blockers), Verapamil (calcium channel blocker) and Digitoxin all control rate so they would be appropriate in the treatment of atrial flutter. Flecanide is a rhythm controlling drug. Membrane active rhythm control medications, such as flecainide  are not recommended for rate control, because the potential pro-arrhythmic effect outweighs the usefulness of rate control.

Question:
You see a 15 year old girl in the GP surgery. She has been experiencing low mood for a number of months and her parents are concerned as she no longer wants to spend time with her friends. On further questioning she reveals that she is having difficulty sleeping and is quite stressed about upcoming exams.

 

You decide to start her on sertraline. Her parents are a bit hesistant and would like to know how the drug works.

 

What is the mechanism of action of SSRIs?
OptionA: Blocks negative feedback loops of noradrenaline and serotonin
OptionB: Inhibits serotonin reuptake, which means serotonin remains in the synaptic cleft for longer
OptionC: Inhibits serotonin and noradrenaline reupatke, so both neurtransmitters remain in the synaptic cleft for longer

Question:
The X-ray of a patient shows that they are suffering from a massive pneumoperitoneum. When asked how the medical student was able to identify this, they explain that both sides of the bowel wall are visible on the X-ray. 

What is this sign called?
Explanation:
A - apple core sign is the constriction of the lumen of the colon by a colorectal cancer. 

B - CORRECT! Rigler's sign is when you are able to see both sides of the bowel wall, because there is free gas pushing on either side of the wall. 

C - Football sign is when the abdomen becomes rugby shaped - due to massive pneumoperitoneum. 

D - Falciform ligament sign - another sign of pneumoperitoneum, where there is gas either side of the falciform ligament. 

E - Thumbprinting - this is when the bowel wall is thickened due to oedema, and is indicative of mesenteric ischaemia.

Question: A mother at the hospital is discovered to be suffering from a partial molar pregnancy. On an echocardiogram, the placenta seems abnormally large but the foetus is abnormally small. You are aware that pregnant women with this abnormality are at an increased risk of choriocarcinoma. She asks you, the F1 working her case, why this is the case, and you explain the cause of this abnormality. What is the abnormality?
Explanation:
A - Incorrect. This is when an individual's germline cells are affected by a mutation and is unrelated to the question.

 

B - Incorrect. Digyny is a type of triploidy caused by the fertilisation of a diploid egg with one sperm cell. It is characterised by both a small placenta and a small foetus, unlike the question scenario which states that the pregnancy has a large placenta and small foetus.

 

C - Incorrect. While the correct answer (D, diandry) is a type of triploidy this answer is not specific enough / is not the single best answer.  

 

D - Correct. Diandry is a type of triploidy caused by the fertilisation of one egg cell with two sperm OR the fertilisation of one egg cell with one diploid sperm cell. As the scenario states, it is characterised by a large placenta and small foetus, and is a partial molar pregnancy w/ increased risk of choriocarcinoma

The initial step in the management of diabetic ketoacidosis should be fluid restoration through IV administration of saline. 

 

NICE and BNF guidelines.

Question: Maria, a 55 year old woman with type 2 diabetes, attends her GP for her annual diabetic review. Despite treatment with metformin and gliclazide, her HbA1c remains above threshold. Her GP prescribes sitagliptin. What is the MoA of this drug?
OptionA: Binds to K+ channels to increase the release of insulin
OptionB: Inhibits the SGLT2 transporter in the kidney
OptionE: Increases insulin sensitivity and decreases hepatic gluconeogenesis
Explanation: Gliptins reduce the peripheral breakdown of incretin by inhibiting DPP-4.

Question: A patient visits you, her GP, with concerns of breast cancer. You decide to perform an ultrasound scan and find malignant lesions in the superior lateral region of the breast. Why are cancerous lesions in the breast most likely to occur in this region?
Explanation:
Each individual breast consists of 4 regions - superior lateral, superior medial, inferior lateral, and inferior medial. These regions, however, are not of equal size. The superior lateral is the biggest as it contains the axillary process and so it is the most likely region for malignancy. 

 

If you answered A: although the axillary lymph nodes are found in the superior lateral region and are the most significant, this is technically not the single best answer.

Question:
You are the FY1 on the night shift in the A&E department. Boris, a 59 year old man, has come to A&E suffering from colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominal distention and constipation. You arrange a AXR, which is shown below. 

What is your diagnosis?
Explanation:
Xray shows SBO and symptoms are consistent with this. This can be identified for three main reasons: 

  • The small bowel is distended > 3cm. 
  • The small bowel has a central location (LB is peripheral).
  • Valvulae conniventes - transverse lines that cross from one side of the bowel to the other (LB has haustra).

See small and large bowel imaging plenary for more.

Question: On placement you come across a patient with mesenteric ischaemia, which makes you think about the arterial supply to the GI tract. Which of the following is not a branch of the superior mesenteric artery?
Explanation: The left colic artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery. The rest are branches of the SMA.

Question:
A 56-year-old woman presents to her physician due to recent onset of chest pain and breathlessness. She also complains of pain in her left arm.

Two weeks prior, the patient suffered a myocardial infarction. Her physical examination is remarkable for a friction rub over the left sternal border, along with an elevated jugular venous pressure.

 

The image below shows her ECG.

 

 

What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
Explanation:
Dressler Syndrome is post-MI syndrome. It usually occurs around 2-3 weeks after an MI. It is caused by a localised immune response and causes pericarditis.

It presents with pleuritic chest pain, low grade fever and a pericardial rub on auscultation. It can cause a pericardial effusion and rarely a pericardial tamponade.

A diagnosis can be made with an ECG (global ST elevation and T wave inversion), echocardiogram (pericardial effusion) and raised inflammatory markers (CRP and ESR).

Management is with NSAIDs (aspirin / ibuprofen) and in more severe cases steroids (prednisolone). They may need pericardiocentesis to remove fluid from around the heart.
Tags: ECG, Cardiology, Cardiovascular System, Case 12, Clinical

Question: What is the function of lactoferrin in breast milk?
OptionC: Inhibits the adhesion of bacteria in different epithelial sites
OptionD: Inhibits the multiplication of microorganisms by chelating iron
Explanation:
Refer to case 8, Anatomy of Breast lecture. 

 

Lactoferrin is an iron chelator. This means it removes iron from the body. Iron is essential for the multiplication of microorganisms. 

 

Easy way to remember it is... Fe = Iron / LactoFerrin

Question: Lactational amenorrhoea is a term coined to describe the contraceptive effect of exclusive breast feeding post-partum. How is this achieved?
Explanation:
Refer to case 8, Anatomy of breast lecture. 

 

Lactational amenorrhoea is achieved by exclusive breast feeding. The high prolactin levels that result from this inhibit the pulsatile release of GnRH from the hypothalamus. Hence, this prevents LH release from anterior pituitary.

Question: A new mother asks her midwife about proper breast-feeding technique. The midwife emphasises the importance of completely emptying the breast, stating that this allows the baby to receive a particular composition of milk. What type of milk is the midwife referring to, and why is this important?
OptionA: Foremilk. Important because it is high in IgA.
OptionB: Hindmilk. Important because it is high in protein.
OptionC: Hindmilk. Important because it is high in IgA.
OptionD: Hindmilk. Important because it is high in lactoferrin.
OptionE: Hindmilk. Important because it is high in fat.
Explanation:
Case 8, Anatomy of breast lecture. 

 

As the breast is emptied, the fat composition of the milk it contains increases. Milk fat globules adhere to alveolar membranes and are displaced only when the gland is near empty.

Question: The first 12-24 hours after fertilization, the zygote undergoes rapid cell division known as cleavage. Which structure inhibits the cells from growing in size during cleavage?
Explanation: During cleavage, the speed of cell division & the glycoprotein structure surrounding the zygote known as the zona pellucida inhibits the growth of the cells. Morula therefore is the same size as the initial zygote.

Question: The sympathetic innervation to the uterus is via which of the following?
Explanation: Sympathetic innervation to the uterus is via the uterovaginal plexus, which is also the main sympathetic nerve supply to the cervix.

Question: What is the origin of the parasympathetic innervation to the uterus?
Explanation: Parasympathetic innervation to the uterus is via the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4).

Question: The uterine artery is the blood supply to the uterus. It branches off of the internal iliac artery, which is a branch of the common iliac artery. At what level does the abdominal aorta bifurcate into the common iliac arteries?
Explanation: Abdominal aorta bifurcates into common iliac arteries at L4.

Question: B lymphocytes are an important cell in our adaptive immune system. They arise from the common lymphoid progenitor cell in the bone marrow. Where do they mature?
Explanation: B cells arise from common lymphoid progenitor cells and mature within the bone marrow. T lymphocytes mature in the thymus.

Question: Increased activity in the myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus leads to increased motility. There are different types of motility in the GI tract. Which of the following is the correct term for "segmental mixing in the colon"?
Explanation:
Peristalsis - propulsion. Sequential contraction of circular and longitudinal smooth muscle. 

Segmentation - mixing. Simultaneous circular contraction. 

Migratory motor complex - clearing undigested food during the fasting state. A sweeping contraction from the gastric antrum to the ileo-caecal valve. 

Haustration - segmental mixing in the colon. 

Mass peristalsis - large movement in the colon. Large waves 1-3 times per day, moving 30cm.

Question: Which of the following is NOT carried out by astrocytes
Explanation: B is carried out by oligodendrocytes. astrocytes promote the myelination of neurons but do not carry out the actual function.

Question: The parotid gland produces approximately 25% of our total saliva. It produces mostly serous saliva, rich in enzymes for digestion. What is the autonomic innervation of the parotid gland, which controls the rate of saliva production?
Explanation: Autonomic innervation to the parotid gland is via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which controls rate of saliva production. Great auricular nerve supplies sensory innervation.

Question: The stomach contains many different cell types with different secretions. What do chief cells secrete, and what is the function?
OptionA: Gastric acid & intrinsic factor - denature proteins & immune protection
OptionC: Somatostatin, inhibit acid and increase mucus production
OptionE: Alkaline mucous, protect epithelium from acid damage
Explanation: Chief cells secrete pepsinogen for protein digestion.

Question: The blood supply to the descending colon is via X. It branches off the abdominal aorta at level Y. What is X and Y?
Explanation:
Blood supply to hindgut is inferior mesenteric artery, branches off the abdominal aorta at L3. 

Coeliac trunk, foregut, T12.

SMA, midgut, L1.

Question: Mr Jones has been diagnosed with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The doctor explains to him that this syndrome is caused by a tumour which secretes which substance?
Explanation: Pancreatic tumours which secrete gastrin. Excessive acid production, which results in severe gastric ulcer disease.

Question: You are a junior doctor on the ward. One of the nurses has asked you to do a 12-lead ECG on Mr Jones, one of the patients. How many electrodes will you place on Mr Jones' chest?
Explanation: In a 12-lead ECG there are 6 chest electrodes.

Question: Cardiac axis gives us an idea of the overall direction of travel of the electrical activity in the heart. What would you expect to observe on an ECG in right ventricular hypertrophy?
OptionA: Lead II has the most positive deflection
OptionB: Lead III has the most positive deflection
OptionC: Lead III has the most positive deflection, lead I is negative.
OptionD: Lead I has the most positive deflection.
OptionE: Lead I has the most positive deflection, II and III are negative.
Explanation:
Normal cardiac axis - lead II has the most positive deflection. 

Right axis deviation - lead III most positive, lead I negative. Right ventricular hypertrophy.

Left axis deviation - lead I most positive, lead II and III negative. Heart conduction abnormalities.

Question: You are interpreting an ECG of a patient on the ward. The PR interval is consistent, but a QRS complex is dropped/missed every 3 p waves. You diagnose heart block, but what type of heart block is described?
Explanation:
First degree - fixed, prolonged PR interval > 200ms 

Mobitz 1 - progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a QRS complex is eventually dropped

Mobitz 2 - QRS dropped every 3rd or 4th p wave, consistent PR interval 

Third degree - no communication between atria and ventricles at all, escape rhythms and buried p waves

Question: Regulation of blood pressure is via the baroreceptor reflex and the RAAS. The first part of the RAAS is the release of renin in response to increased concentration of salt in the blood or stimulation from the SNS. Where is renin released from?
Explanation: Renin is released from the juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney.

Question: Renin converts angiotensinogen into angiotensin I. Where is angiotensinogen produced?
Explanation: Angiotensinogen produced by liver

Question:
A 46 year old woman presents to the GP with a 3 day history of loose stools, abdominal pain and vomiting. On further questioning the GP finds out that she went to a reasturant with a group of friends 5 days ago and 2 of them are experiencing similar symptoms.

 

The GP also takes her temperature, which is 37.9 degrees, and sends off a stool culture which contains curved gram negative rods.

 

Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause of her symptoms?
Explanation:
Campylobacter is the most common bacterial cause of diarrhoea in the UK.

It is usually contacted from eating undercooked poultry or pork.

It is also a gram negative, curved and flagellated rod.

 

It is a notifiable disease and can also cause Guillian-Barre symptoms.

 

The rest of the choices are also causes of diarrhoea but are not as common.
Tags: Abdomen, Case 15, Infections, Infectious Disease, Infectious Organisms

Question: Harry experiences blunt force trauma to his eye on a night out, after falling on his face. This results in damage to the floor of his bony orbit. Which sinus will the contents of the orbit herniate into in this case?
Explanation: The floor of the orbit separates the orbital cavity from the maxillary sinus. The medial wall and the floor of the orbit are the weakest and can become damaged in blunt force trauma to the eye. In medial wall damage, the contents of the orbital cavity will herniate into the ethmoid sinus, in floor damage, the contents will herniate into maxillary sinus.

Question: Mr Smith comes in to your GP surgery and presents with lower back pain which does not radiate down his legs. It has been going on for 4 weeks now and finds it gets worse at work when he is bricklaying. He has not previously taken any painkillers for his lower back pain as he wanted your advice first. What medication would you recommend to Mr Smith?
Explanation:
NICE recommends NSAIDs and weak opioids for acute lower back pain as paracetamol has been found to be ineffective at managing lower back pain in trials. Using the WHO pain ladder we would use NSAIDs first and see if these are effective, if not you could move onto weak opioids (with or without paracetamol) but only for a short amount of time.

Amitriptyline can be used in patients presenting with lower back pain alongside radicular pain (sciatica)

https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng59

You would also recommend exercise/staying active, lifestyle modifications and physiotherapy if indicated with his acute lower back pain.

Question:
You are a third year on placement and the orthopaedic consultant asks you about the anatomy of the back. She asks you to name the three intermediate muscles of the back. When combined, these muscles are referred to as erector spinae. 

 

What is the correct combination of muscles?
Explanation:
Extrinsic muscles of the back: 

  • Latissimus dorsi 
  • Trapezius 
  • Rhomboid major and minor 

Intrinsic muscles of the back (superficial) - also known as intermediate muscles: 

  • Longissimus 
  • Ileocostalis 
  • Spinalis 

 

Intrinsic muscles of the back (deep): 

  • short deep muscles

Question: If the posterior spinal arteries became occluded, which of the following pathways would be affected?
Explanation: The posterior spinal arteries supply the posterior section of the spinal cord (the dorsal aspect). The dorsal column pathway lies in the dorsal section of the spinal cord therefore occlusion of the these arteries would cause a lack of bloody supply to the posterior spinal cord resulting in dorsal column syndrome. There would be loss of vibration and proprioception.

Question:
Natalie has recently suffered a C5 disc prolapse and is experiencing tingling and numbness in the lateral spect of her hand. 

 

Which of the following nerve roots would be compressed and causing the above symptoms?
Explanation:
The nerve root would be C6 because in the cervical spine, the corresponding peripheral nerve exits the spinal cord above the vertebrae. However, from T1 to S5, the nerve root exits below the vertebrae. 

 

For example, the T3 nerve root would exit below the T3 vertebrae, however on the contrary, the C7 nerve root would exit above the C7 vertebrae. This is because there are 8 cervical nerve roots even though there are 7 cervical vertebrae. Whereas, the thoracic, lumbar and sacral nerve roots are the same in number as the vertebrae.

Question: The vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the heart, where it synapses with postganglionic fibres in the SAN and AVN. Which receptors will acetylcholine bind in the SAN and AVN to decrease heart rate?
Explanation: Acetylcholine binds M2 receptors in the SAN and AVN, which decreases the slop of the pacemaker potential to decrease heart rate (a negative chronotropic effect).

Question: Noradrenaline acts on which receptors in the heart?
Explanation: Release of noradrenaline from the postganglionic fibres of the sympathetic trunk, binds to B1 adrenoceptors in the heart to increase slop of pacemaker potential to increase heart rate and inotropic effects.

Question: A patient comes into A and E as they have been experiencing bloody diarrhoea for a week. Which of the following organisms does not result in bloody diarrhoea?
Explanation:
E - giardia is a protozoan which causes giardiasis which can be seen as cysts in contaminated water and will cause foul smelling fatty diarrhoea. 

A, B and D are all bacteria 

While C is a protozoan which causes amebiasis which causes bloody diarrhoea and liver abscesses.

Question: A patient is experiencing watery diarrhoea - which of the following organisms would not cause watery diarrhoea?
Explanation:
Salmonella Enteritides is the second most common cause of infectious diarrhoea behind campylobacter Jejuni. It causes bloody diarrhoea and complications of salmonella enteritides can include: bacteriaemia, reactive arthritis, osteomyelitis in sickle cell disease. 

The remaining options all cause water diarrhoea and can be remembered using V REC the GI NORA

Question: A 83 year old man presents to A+E with acute epigastric pain and stool with fresh blood. You suspect it is an acute occlusion of an artery. What is the most likely artery to be occluded?
Explanation:
There are a number of cause of superior mesenteric artery occlusion, including thrombosis, embolism, abdominal aortic aneurysm and aortic dissection.

Often acute, occlusion of the SMA restricts blood flow to the midgut, resulting in intestinal ischaemia. It is more common in the elderly, and most usually presents with abdominal pain. The most useful investigation in this scenario is CT scan of the abdomen.

Treatment is surgical.

Reference: https://teachmeanatomy.info/abdomen/vasculature/arteries/superior-mesenteric/

Question: Which of the following is NOT a respiratory cause of clubbing
Explanation: COPD will not cause clubbing of the fingernails

Question: The 6 in 1 vaccine is given at 8,12 and 16 weeks. Which of the following is NOT given as part of the 6 in 1.
Explanation:
6 in 1 vaccine: diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (whooping cough), polio, haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and hepatitis B. Given via the thigh. 

 

Meningococcal group B (MenB) vaccine is given separately at 8 weeks, 16 weeks and 1 year (booster). 

 

Case 9 - routine immunisation schedule - https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/vaccinations/nhs-vaccinations-and-when-to-have-them/

Question: Which of the following structures in the female reproductive tract is a remnant of lower part of the gubernaculum?
Explanation:
Round ligament is remnant of gubernaculum. 

 

Upper gubernaculum - ovarian ligament

Lower gubernaculum - round ligament of the uterus

Question: The term that best describes a benign tumour of fibrous tissue is:
Explanation:
Adenoma: benign tumour of glandular tissue

Fibroma: benign tumour of fibrous tissue

Lipoma: benign tumour of fat tissue

Papilloma: benign tumour with a papillary architecture

Question: Most common metastasis site is:
Explanation:
The MOST common site is BONE

 

Other common sites are:

- liver

- lung

- brain

Question: Which of the following is not a characteristic of the the second stage of labour pain?
OptionA: it occurs from full cervical dilation to delivery
OptionE: perineum receives innervation from s2-s3 via lumbar sacral plexus
Explanation: The first stage of labour pain is visceral crampy, poorly localised pain involving slow unmyelinated C fibres

Question: Maisie is diagnosed with a UTI, caused by E. Coli infection. What is the structure of this organism?
Explanation: E coli is a common cause of UTIs and is a gram negative rod

Question: You are presented with an ECG. You conclude that the ECG may suggest left bundle branch block (LBBB). What features were seen on the ECG?
OptionA:
Prolonged QRS complex 

Deep 'W shaped" R wave (V1)

Notched 'M shaped' R wave (V6)
OptionB:
Prolonged PR interval

Fixed PR interval

Intermittent non conducting P-waves
OptionC:
Prolonged QRS complex

'M' shaped R wave (V1)

Deep, 'W shaped' S wave (V6)
Explanation:
A= LBBB

 

B = Classic ECG presentation for second degree heart block (Mobitz type II)

 

C = RBBB (right bundle branch block)

 

D = Atrial Fibrillation

 

A good way to remember the difference between LBBB and RBBB is:

LBBB - WiLLiaM

- W shaped R waves in V1

- LL - left bundle branch block

- M shaped R waves in V6

 

RBBB - MoRRoW

- M shaped R wave in V1

- RR - right bundle branch block

- W shaped S waves in v6

However this is not always easily seen therefore does not always work

Question: What type of drug is flecainide?
Explanation: drugs to manage cardaic arryhtmias plenary

Question:
A patient presents to A&E with a severely injured leg. His friend tells you that he had a high impact fall following a bullet being shot into the back of his leg, which he believes is still inside.

 

You would like to have some imaging of his leg done to determine the appropriate management for this patient, as you want to better determine the trauma to his bones, and the surrounding soft tissue. 

 

You would like to minimise the amount of radiation for this patient, as he recently had a CT of his abdomen for suspected small bowel obstruction, which you know has approximately 3 years of background radiation associated with this scan.

 

What imaging would you want to do?
Explanation:
XR - fast, readily available, provides good imaging of bone (and surrounding soft tissue). Although it uses ionisation radiation (approx. 10 days of background radiation), it is the best option for this specific patient 

 

MRI - great for looking at soft tissue detail and also does not use ionising radiation. Therefore this would potentially be a good option. However, the patient has presented with a potential bullet still inside his leg therefore cannot have an MRI. Contraindications for MRI scans include metal objects inside the body e.g., bullets, aneurysm clips, heart pacemakers (if not MRI-compatible).

 

DEXA - Although DEXA scans are quick, non-invasive and have low radiation, they are not very useful for imaging. They are best used to measure bone mineral density and confirm conditions such as osteoporosis. 

 

CT - Higher levels of ionising radiation compared to XR, therefore XR would be favoured.

 

 

(Case 14 - Radiology of the spine lecture)

Question: During coronary angiography, the femoral artery can be accessed via the femoral triangle. Which of the following forms the medial border of the femoral triangle?
Explanation:
A = fascia lata is the roof 

B = pectineus, iliopsoas and adductor longus is the floor 

C = inguinal ligament is superior border 

D = sartorius is lateral border 

E = adductor longus is medial border of femoral triangle

Question:
There are different ways of paralysing people using neuromuscular blockages, as they have multiplee different action sites. Botulinum, atracurium and suxamethonium are neuromuscular blockages.


Which statement correcty outlines how they work?
OptionA: Botulinum - Increases ACh release. Has a long duration and slow onset.
OptionC: Atracurium - competitive antagonist of ACh post-synaptic receptors at a neuromuscular junction.
Explanation:
Botulinum – blocks ACh release (turns muscles off). Not used in anaesthesia. Long duration, slow onset.

 

Suxamethonium – depolarisation (uncommon) works in 60seconds, lasts minutes
- Bind to ACh post synaptic receptors
- Single type in clinical use
- Competitive agonist
- Acts in addition to ACh
- Fasciculations


Atracurium – non depolarising (most common) works in 2-3 minutes and lasts 20-30 minutes
- Bind to ACh post synaptic receptors
- Many types in clinical use
- Block’s action of ACh
- Competitive antagonist
- Not broken down
- No Fasciculations

Question: Patent ductus arteriosus is a condition that can occur if the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. Which two structures does the ductus arteriosus connect in utero?
OptionB: Inferior vena cava & arch of the aorta
Explanation: The ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary artery with the descending aorta; no need for blood to go to lungs in the womb when not in use; therefore blood directed to the descending aorta to be sent to rest of body.

Question: Mr Davies, a 75 year old male comes to the GP practice with symptoms of syncope. The doctor measures his pulse and he's found to be severely bradycardic. In his past medical history, he had mentioned he had an MI and is on an AVN blocker. An ECG is performed showing he has an increased P: QRS ratio, but has a fixed PR interval. What is the most likely diagnosis
Explanation: Although B is correct, D is more accurate and therefore is the single best answer.

Question:
A 40 year old female patient presents to you with back pain that came on suddenly yesterday, that has not gone away. She cannot remember exactly when it started. She lets you know that she banged her back on the corner of the worktop and wonders if this is related. You note from her medical history that she takes prednisolone regularly.

 

On general inspection of her back, you observe that there are no penetrating wounds or scars however there seems to be a degree of spinal deformity. 

 

What would you be suspecting in this patient?
Explanation:
Spinal infection - no mention of pyrexia/chills/rigour or penetrating wound (potential source of infection) or other recent infection

 

Spinal fracture - sudden onset, severe pain. This patient is on regular corticosteroids, which increases her risk of osteoporosis (and bone fragility due to decreased bone mass density +micro-architectural deterioration of bone tissue). Due to this, it is likely that when she banged herself against the corner of the worktop that she could have fractured her spine. This would explain the severe pain and spinal deformity. 

 

Spinal tumour - this could have been a possibility however it would potentially be coupled with 1) unintentional weight loss 2) pain that wakes patient up in the night 3) longer duration of back pain (as opposed to only having the pain for one day) 4) other red flags e.g., family history of cancer or history of cancer. Also if you're under 50 you have a lower risk

 

Ankylosing spondylitis - tends to present in early adulthood. 'Classic presentation': association with conditions with same genetic association (HLA B27 gene); local inflammation in the affected areas; deep pain in lower buttock/lumbar region

 

 

*Taken from the spinal pathology lectures* CASE 14

Question: What molecule mentioned below acts as a chemoattractant which leaves a 'breadcrumb trail' for the activated cDc's to enter the lymphoid tissue?
Explanation:
If a PRR is triggered by a PAMP, the chemokine receptor CCR7 is upregulated.
CCL21 is a chemoattractant for these activated cDCs (with CCR7) as it is produced in the lymph nodes, leaving a breadcrumb trail which the cDCs can now follow to the lymph node.

Case 9 Immunology 2 lecture

Question: which of these best describes the decidual reaction?
OptionA: implantation of the zygote into the wall of the uterus
OptionB: the removal of proteins from the plasma membrane of sperm overlying the acrosomal region in order for sperm to be able to pass through the corona radiata
OptionC: the changing of the stromal cells in the uterine walls in response to an implanting blastocyst causing them to thicken
OptionD: the process in which a zygote changes into a morula
OptionE: the formation of the neural place initiated by the primary inductive event
Explanation:
the decidual reaction happens early pregnancy when the blastocyst implants into the endometrium.

A is wrong as the zygote doesn't implant

B is called capacitation

D is called cleavage 

E is neuralation

Question: What are the white and grey matter changes of the brain during adolescence?
OptionA:
white matter = non linear increase 

grey matter = linear increase
OptionB:
white matter = increase at start and level off 

grey matter = u shaped curve
OptionC:
white matter = linear increase

grey matter = inverted u shaped curve, non linear progression and regression
OptionE:
white matter = linear increase

grey matter = linear increase

Question: What part of the basal ganglia is involved in subconscious regulation of movement?
Explanation:
A - putamen regulates movement linked to substantial nigra

B - caudate nucleus is involved in memory and learning

C - correct

D - regulation of sleep, awareness, relaying sensory information 

E - not part of basal ganglia

Question: A patient is diagnosed with Verner Morrison syndrome which is a neuroendocrine tumour involved in over-secreting VIP which results in excessive water diarrhoea. Which of the following is not correctly matched?
OptionA: enterochromaffin cells secrete serotonin for chloride secretion
OptionB: D cells secrete somatostatin for sodium and chloride secretion
OptionC: Enteric neurones secrete serotonin for sodium absorption
OptionD: NANC neurones secrete VIP for chloride secretion
Explanation: Enteric neurones secrete enkephalins for sodium absorption

Question: You are shadowing Dr Johns on your orthopaedic placement. They are discussing spinal metastases with you and ask you which part of the spine is the commonest site of metastasis? How would you respond?
Explanation: The most common site for spinal metastases is the thoracic spine because there are more thoracic vertebrae (12). The second commonest site is the lumbar spine as the lumbar vertebrae are bigger.

Question: What type of gene is APC?

Mrs Jones is at the GP for her routine check-up and after doing some research online the night before, on medication for depression she came across ketamine. Mrs Jones was quite skeptical about this drug and wanted to ask the GP how it worked. Which of the following best describes it's mechanism of action?
OptionA: Agonist of NMDA receptors, increasing the binding and intake of glutamate
OptionB: Agonist of NMDA receptors, increasing the binding and intake of serotonin
OptionC: Antagonist of NMDA receptors, preventing the binding of glutamate
OptionD: Antagonist of NMDA receptors, preventing the binding of serotonin
Explanation:
A, B, D are made up

E - MOA of typical antipsychotics 

Ketamine is an antagonist of NMDA receptors preventing the binding of glutamate. Therefore ketamine has anaesthetic, psychotic and antidepressant effects.

Question: A patient presents to A&E with sudden and rapidly intensifying pain in the upper right region of their abdomen, nausea, vomiting and jaundice. The doctor suspects gallstones causing post-hepatic jaundice. Which of the following would not be a clinical finding in post-hepatic jaundice?
Explanation:
In post-hepatic jaundice you will get raised ALP

ALP is raised in biliary obstruction (as well as bone disease, during pregnancy and certain malignancies) however GGT is more specific for biliary obstruction than ALP

A - Pale stools due to failure of conjugated bilirubin to reach the small intestine due to biliary obstruction, leading to reduced stercobilin entering the GI tract, which normally colours the stool

C - Dark urine due to conjugated bilirubin being water soluble and being excreted in the urine giving its dark colour 

D - High GGT due to biliary obstruction (more specific than ALP)

E - Conjugated bilirubin is formed in liver, but due to obstruction cannot enter small intestine so leaks into bloodstream causing high levels

Question: A medical student is on placement in Royal Gwent and is curious about antibiotic resistance. He asks the FY1 doctor to describe the physiology behind how bacteria build resistance to certain antibiotics. The FY1 describes how some bacteria express an enzyme that cleaves a part of a certain antibiotic inactivating it. What is the mechanism of action of the antibiotic that this enzyme acts on?
OptionA: Inhibits the action of topoisomerase IV and DNA gyrase
OptionD: Beta-lactam ring that inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to PBPs (penicillin binding proteins) preventing the final transpeptidal step of peptidoglycan synthesis
OptionE: Bind to 30s subunit of bacterial ribosomes, inhibiting protein synthesis
Explanation:
A - fluroquinolones

B - rimfampicin

C - Sulphonamides and trimethoprim

D - Penicilins and cephalosporins (Beta-lactam antibiotics)

E - Tetracyclines and ahminoglycosides

Question: Which of the following is not true about the sensory memory storage site?
OptionA: Lasts up to 1/2 a second for visual information and 2-4 seconds for auditory information
OptionC: Where information first enters for the brain to filter information coming in from the environment
OptionD: Includes the phonological loop, visuospatial sketchpad and central executive
OptionE: Information is ignored or processed depending on it's relevance
Explanation:
The phonological loop, visuospatial sketchpad and central executive is part of working memory not sensory memory storage site. 

The working memory is a system that allows for the temporary storage and manipulation of information to allow for reasoning, learning and comprehension

Question: Which cell cycle checkpoint is responsible for checking that the DNA has been copied properly?
Explanation:
G1S: Checkpoint which makes sure DNA is intact before entering S phase

G2M: Checkpoint which makes sure DNA has been copied correctly before entering mitosis

Spindle Assembly: Checkpoint which ensures that the chromosomes are attached correctly to the spindles (between metaphase and anaphase)

Question: One of these is NOT a tumour suppressor gene. Which one?
Explanation: KRAS is a proto-oncogene

Question:
I am explaining chemotherapy drugs to my housemates:

 

'This drug is a TOPOISOMERASE INHIBITOR. It prevents unwinding of supercoiled DNA double strands and hence inhibits any subsequent DNA replication activity in rapidly dividing cells."

 

What drug am I talking about?
Explanation:
A. Cyclophosphamide is an ALKYLATING AGENT

B. Doxorubicin is a TOPOISOMERASE INHIBITOR

C. Fluorouracil is an ANTI-METABOLITES

D. Letrozole is an AROMATASE INHIBITOR

E. Paclitaxel is a MICROTUBULE MODIFYING AGENT

Question:
I am explaining chemotherapy drugs to my housemates:

 

"This drug is an ANTI-METABOLITES. It interferes with purine or pyrimidine biosynthesis. This medication's active metabolite F-dUMP inhibits thymidylate synthase, preventing thymidine triphosphate generation."

 

What chemotherapy drug am I talking about?
Explanation:
A. Doxorubicin is a TOPOISOMERASE INHIBITOR

 

B. Fluorouracil is an ANTI-METABOLITES

     Indicated for certain breast, colorectal, pancreatic, and gastric cancers

 

C. Imatinib is a TYROSINE KINASE INHIBITOR

 

D. Paclitaxel is a MICROTUBULE MODIFYING AGENT

 

E. Tamoxifen is a RECEPTOR MODULATOR

Question:
I am explaining chemotherapy drugs to my housemates:

 

" This drug is a MICROTUBULE MODIFYING AGENT. This type of medication can either prevent polymerisation OR prevent depolymerisation of microtubules attached to replicated chromosomes during mitotic division. Uncouples cancerous mitosis as a consequence."

 

Which of these is an example of the type of chemotherapy being described?
Explanation:
A. Cyclophosphamide is an ALKALATING AGENT

 

B. Doxorubicin is a TOPOISOMERASE INHIBITOR

 

C. Letrozole is an AROMATASE INHIBITOR

 

D. Paclitaxel is a MICROTUBULE MODIFYING AGENT

     Indicated for ceratin ovarian, breast, and lung cancers

 

E. Tamoxifen is a RECEPTOR MODULATOR

Question:
I am explaining chemotherapy medications to my housemates:

 

"This drug is an ALKYLATING AGENT. It chemically reacts with guanine nucleotides causing them to cross-link, preventing DNA strand synthesis and replication. Triggers apoptosis as a result"

 

What drug am I talking about?
Explanation:
A. Cyclophospanide is an ALKYLATING AGENT

     Indicated for acute and chronic leukemias

 

B. Doxorubicin is a TOPOISOMERASE INHIBITOR

 

C. Fluorouracil is an ANTI-METABOLITE

 

D. Letrozole is an AROMATASE INHIBITOR

 

E. Paclitaxel is a MICROTUBLE MODIFYING AGENT

Question: Mrs Smith has back pain, she goes to her GP and he refers her to get some imaging done. She has a myelogram done, where is the contrast injected into?
Explanation: injected into subarachnoid space under fluoroscopy and Mrs Smith will go to have a CT

Question:
A young woman suspected of meningitis is brought in. Due to her condition, the consultant does not think a lumbar puncture would be most suitable to test for meningitis. 

Which of the following does not describe a contraindication to performing a lumbar puncture for suspected meningitis?
OptionC: A cut at the site of puncture
Explanation: Pregnancy is the only one not contradindicated by a lumbar puncture

Question: What muscle is the only muscle in the anterior compartment of the thigh, not innervated by the femoral nerve?
Explanation: psoas major is innervated by the anterior rami of the L1-L3 nerves - gracilis is a medial compartment muscle

Question: What is the name of the drug that acts to prevent oestrogen production, oestrogen being a key driver in some cancer cell formations?
Explanation: Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor - preventing conversion of androgens to oestrogens

Question: A woman has a new cancer diagnosis in which is states the cancer is 'well differentiated'. What would her prognosis be and why?
OptionA: Poor prognosis, cancer cells are very different to tissue of origin
OptionB: Good prognosis, cancer cells will not spread
OptionC: Good prognosis, cancer cells are similar to tissue of origin
OptionD: Poor prognosis, cancer cells have a high mitotic rate
Explanation:
C is correct.

B is partially correct however the grade of the cancer does not mean it wont spread.

Stage is whether it spreads

Grade - looking at cancer cells under a microscope and seeing how similar they are to surronding tissue

Question: What 'hall mark of cancer' is thalidomide related to?
Explanation:
Case 16

Thalidomide is an inhibitor of angiogenesis

Question: Which typical antipsychotic is most likely to cause hyperprolactinaemia?
Explanation:
Haloperidol - high potency typical antipsychotic - more likely to cause EPSEs & hyperprolactinaemia

 

Chlorpromazine & Thioridazine - lower potency - opposite effects of Haloperidol, but more likely to have anticholinergic effects & sedation

 

Olanzapine & Aripiprazole = ATYPICAL antipsychotics

Question: Which 2nd generation antipsychotic drug is associated with agranulocytosis?
Explanation:
Haloperidol & Thioridazine = typical/1st gen

 

Rest are 2nd gen/atypical

 

Clozapine associated with agranulocytosis (bone marrow not producing WBCs)

- high risk of developing **leucopenia**
- and develop **neutropenia** (low levels of neutrophils in blood)
- weakened immune system - susceptible to getting dangerous infections
- **requires regular blood tests to check WBCs**

Question: Mrs Jones, a 67 year old female, has presented to her GP because of an upset stomach. Upon further questioning, Mrs Jones reveals that she hasn't been very strict with her taking her medication and often 'doubles up' on her Bisoprolol, Omeprazole and Chlorpromazine if she forgets to take a dose. The GP notices that her lips are smacking together. What is this sign called?
Explanation:
- Acute Dystonia: muscle spasms that mainly affect head, neck and tongue (also, can cause spasm of the extraocular muscles of the eye causing olucogyric crisis - upward & outward deviation of eyes) - hours to days
- Akathisia: restlessness - days to months
- Parkinsonism: including bradykinesia, tremors, muscle rigidity (in facial muscles) - days to months
- Tardive dyskinesia: constant involuntary rhythmic movements (esp in lips causing 'lip smacking') - can be **IRREVERSIBLE** unlike other - presents months to years

Question: What pathway is involved in processing and planning?
Explanation: Nueoranatomy C10

Question: What is seen in both neuroleptic malignant syndrome and serotonin syndrome?

Kim Kardashian, a 39 year old female, presented in A&E 3 weeks ago after being involved in a high speed car crash. It was later revealed that she suffered a traumatic brain injury that affected her hypothalamus. Upon recovery, she does not appear to have any desire for food and has since lost 10kg. Which area of the hypothalamus is associated with a lack of desire for food after being destroyed?
Explanation:
Lateral nuclei (feeding centre): stimulation causes excessive feeding. Destruction causes lack of desire for food

Dorsomedial nuclei: lesions often depress eating behaviour

Ventromedial nuclei (satiety centre): stimulation causes satiety even with highly appetizing food. Destruction causes continued eating

Paraventricular nuclei: lesions often cause excessive eating

Arcuate nuclei: Has a role in both increasing and decreasing appetite. (Site of convergence of multiple hormones released by Gi tract and adipose tissue that regulate appetite/energy expenditure.)

Question: What function does the enzyme phosphofructokinase (PFK) have in glycolysis when its allosteric site is phosphorylated?
Explanation:
A: PFK when allosteric site is dephosphorylated 

C: Hexokinase action

D: Pyruvate kinase action
Tags: Metabolism, PCS 1 releasing energy from food

Question:
A laboratory scientist is looking into serotonin and its roles within the gut. 

When studying the serotonin synthesis pathway, he notices it has a rate limiting step.

From the options below, identify the correct stage in the synthesis process AND the enzyme associated with this rate limiting step.
Explanation:
The correct answer is B - tryptophan --> 5-hydroxytryptophan by tryptophan hydroxylase

 

The pathway is as follows: 

tryptophan --> 5-hydroxytryptophan by tryptophan hydroxylase

5-hydroxytryptophan --> 5- Tryptophan hydroxylase (5-HT) by 5-HP-decarboxylase

 

5-HT can be further broken down by MAO (monoamine oxidase) to form 5-HIAA but this is past the stage of creating serotonin which is 5-HT

 

See psychopharmacology lectures 1 and 2 for more info and a good diagram!!

Question: A group of researchers decide to investigate the efficacy of a new COVID-19 vaccine. They do so by comparing the incidence of COVID-19 between two populations, one that is vaccinated (n = 100) and one that is unvaccinated (n = 100). In the vaccinated group, only 10 participants become infected with COVID. In the unvaccinated group, 76 participants become infected. What is the efficacy of the vaccine?
Explanation:
Refer to case 9, Adult and Child immunisation lecture. 

 

The efficacy of a vaccine (VE) is determined by the following formula:

 

All you need to do is substitute the values. 

 

VE = (76 - 10) /  76 = 0.868 = 87%

Question: What causes the anti psychotic side effect of sedation?
Explanation:
Drug treatment for psychosis
• All antipsychotics are dopamine antagonists
• Clinical effect on mesolimbic pathway
• Other effects
• Sedation Anti-H1
• Postural hypotension Alpha-1-adrenoceptor blockade
• Hyperprolactinaemia D2 blockade in tuberoinfundibular pathway
• QTc prolongation
• Metabolic syndrome
• EPSEs
• Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

Question: What causes the anti psychotic drug effect of postural hypotension?
Explanation:
Drug treatment for psychosis
• All antipsychotics are dopamine antagonists
• Clinical effect on mesolimbic pathway
• Other effects
• Sedation Anti-H1
• Postural hypotension Alpha-1-adrenoceptor blockade
• Hyperprolactinaemia D2 blockade in tuberoinfundibular pathway
• QTc prolongation
• Metabolic syndrome
• EPSEs
• Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

Question: You are a second year medical student - just chilling in the library when suddenly another medic approaches you. They ask for your help as they have forgotten what the alternative pathway of the compliment system is activated by. What is your answer?
Explanation:
A is correct. Micorbial surfaces activate the alternative compliment pathway and C3 binds to these microbial surfaces. This causes recruitment of Factor B and Factor D forming the C3bBb complex and C3 convertase.

B - Tissue Factor activates the extrinsic pathway in the clotting cascade 

C - is made up 

D - Activates the Lectin pathway activating mannose binding lectin 

E - Activates the classical pathway activating c1q
Tags: Virology, Immune Response, Immune System, Immunology, Infections

Question:
Mery's blood group is A

 

When needing a blood transfusion, which blood groups can she receive from?

When needing a plasma transfusion, which blood group can she receive from?
OptionA:
Blood transfusion from groups A and AB

Plasma transfusion from groups A and O
OptionB:
Blood transfusions from groups AB

Plasma transfusion from groups B only
OptionC:
Blood transfusions from groups A and O

Plasma transfusion from groups A and AB
OptionD:
Blood transfusion from groups O only

Plasma transfusion from groups A only
Explanation:
Red Blood Cell

- A can give to A and AB

- B can give to B and AB

- AB can only give to AB

- O universal giver

 

Plasma and platelets

- A can give to A and O

- B can give to B and O

- AB universal giver

- O can only give to O
Tags: Blood Groups, Blood Transfusion, Blood grouping, Case 8

Question: You are a second year medical student on placement and perform an ECG on Mr Hart. You notice some abnormalities and come to the diagnosis of Mobitz Type II heart block. What have you noticed on the ECG?
OptionC: Constant PR interval but there is a drop in a QRS complex
OptionD: Progressive prolongation of PR interval until eventually the QRS complex is dropped
OptionE: Complete dissociation between P wave and QRS complex
Explanation:
The correct answer is C

In 2nd degree heart block - Mobitz type II the PR intervals remain constant until a QRS complex is dropped 

A - 1st degree heart block 

B - This is characteristic of AF which would also have an irregularly irregular rhythm 

D - This is 2nd degree heart block - Mobitz I. Here the PR interval gets longer and longer until eventually a QRS complex is dropped 

E - This is 3rd degree heart block

Question: A 56 year old gentleman presents to the GP clinic following sensory loss in his limbs. He complains that it is worse in his legs than his arms. You note that he has paralysis to the right side of his body. You perform a CT scan and note a dark patch on the CT. What is this patient suffering with?
OptionB: Left sided ischaemic stroke affecting the ACA
OptionD: Left sided ischaemic stroke affecting the PICA
Explanation:
The correct answer is B :) We can rule out A, C and E as these are all haemorrhagic injuries or strokes which would present with acute blood so the CT would show a bright white section where the haemorrhage occurs.

D is incorrect as this would present with ipsilateral facial pain and temperature loss as well as ataxia

B is correct because it is an ischemic stroke which would present with a dark area on the CT. It causes contralateral hemiparesis thus explaining the paralysis on the right side of his body. Sensory loss is also worse in the lower limbs compared to the upper. In an MCA stroke sensory loss is worse in the upper limbs.
Tags: Neural damage, Neuroanatomy, Neurophysiology, Case 13, strokes

Question:
Paul is a 12-year-old skater boy that comes into the emergency unit after a horrible fall.

His mother tells you his Blood group, O.

What would you give Paul?
Explanation:
Red Blood Cell groups:

- Group A can give RBC to groups A and AB

- Group B can give RBC to groups B and AB

- Group AB can only give RBC to group AB

- Group O is a universal giver but can only receive group O 

 

Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) is only given to people born before 1996

Solvent detergent plasma is given to people born after 1996

 

Platelets are only given if:

- Platelet disorders

- Thrombocytopenia

- Extreme bleeds
Tags: Blood Groups, Blood Transfusion, Blood grouping, Case 8

Question: Which one of these is NOT a reason to give irridiated blood?
Explanation:
Reasons for giving irradiated blood:

- bone marrow transplant patient

- transfusion from family or HLA mathed donor

- patient tho have had treatment with purine analogue

- Hodgkin's disease

- intrauterine and exchange transfusion

- severe combined immunodeficiency patient

 

Thrombocytopenia is one of the reason to give paltelets.

Question: You and your housemates are discussing which cancer is the most common in the UK. You are all arguing over who is right. Which housemate is right?
Explanation:
A is correct!

Breast is the most common cancer in the UK affecting 1 in 7 people - males and females but more common in females

Lung Cancer is the most common cause of death in the most deprived 

Bowel is the 4th most common cancer 

Prostate is more common in men over the age of 75

Cervical is the 14th most common

Question: A 78 year old gentleman presents to the GP clinic following a PSA test. You regretfully have to break the bad news to him, stating that the results have returned and they are higher than normal. You think back to that lecture you had in year 2 and try to recall one of the hallmarks of cancer which is resisting cell death. What is the mechanism?
OptionB: There is a mutation in the tumour suppressor gene
OptionC: The cancer cells have downregulated MHCI and over-expressed PD L1
OptionD: There is a mutation in the p53 protein
OptionE: The cancer cells have upregulated MHCI and inhibit the expression of PD L1
Explanation:
The correct answer is D :) - There are 8 different hallmarks of cancer, the one we were looking at here was resisting cell death. This occurs when there is a mutation in the p53 protein. When there is a mutation p53 is not activated so cytochrome C and caspases are also not activated. This results in any DNA damage not being apoptosed so cell death is resisted.

A - This is the mutation that causes immortality to be achieved 

B - This is the mutation that causes evasion of growth factors

C - This causes cancers to evade the immune system 

E - This is a load of rubbish

Question: Which one of these is NOT one of the 4 main functions of the decidua?
OptionA: A source of nourishment for the early embryo
OptionC: Helps form the maternal component of the placenta
OptionD: Promotes the formation of 'blood islands' coming from the mesoderm
OptionE: Forms a cleavage plane: the placenta and membranes separate from the uterus during labor.
Explanation:
The 4 main functions of the decidua are:

 

- a source of nourishment for the early embryo

- Limits invasiveness of the trophoblasts

- Helps the maternal component of the placenta

- Forms a cleavage plane: the placenta and membranes separate from the uterus furing labor

Question: Tim is unwell with a viral infection but he is forcing himself to revise his case 9 immunology notes. How exactly do sentinel cells detect the presence of a pathogen?
Explanation:
TLR4 responsible - example of a Pattern Recognition Receptor (PRR) that is **germ-line encoded**

PRRs known as the 'molecular tripwires' of the innate immune system

 

Sentinel cells:

include macrophages and dendritic cells and a few NK cells

very few lymphocytes present (T and B cells) and of a **memory type**

langerhans cells are a distinct sub-population of self-renewing DCs

Question: Which TLRs can recognise viral glycoproteins?
T cells that are not activated by antigen presented by DC exit the lymph node via the...
Explanation: T cells not activated by antigen presented by DC exit the lymph node via the cortical sinuses and enters the efferent lymphatic vessel

Question: What are the only cells that can present with cross presentation?
Explanation:
**Cross presentation** refers to the ability of endocytosed material to escape the endosomal compartment and reach the cytoplasm, therefore acquiring the ability to be presented by **MHC Class I molecules**. As a result, cDCs do not need to be directly infected by a given virus in order to present viral antigens in association with MHC class I.

Dendritic cells = only cells that can present with cross presentation

Question: Mr Jones has been admitted to hospital with a serious bacterial infection that has become progressively worse. The consultant decides to treat him using gentamicin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic. Gentamicin is strongly associated with toxicity to which of the following?
Explanation: Gentamicin is known to cause ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity. It is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections.

Question: Sophie is prescribed trimethoprim by her GP for a UTI. What is the MoA of trimethoprim?
Explanation:
MoA of trimethoprim is dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor - it inhibits folic acid formation. 

 

--> Antibiotic MoAs

Question: The main determinant of GFR is the state of vasoconstriction of the renal artery tree. Which of the following causes afferent arteriole dilatation and therefore, increased GFR?
Explanation:
Nitric oxide, ANP and prostaglandins all cause afferent arteriole dilatation and therefore increase GFR.

Angiotensin II in high doses, noradrenaline, ADH and adenosine cause afferent arteriole constriction which acts to reduce the GFR. 

 

Dr Johnson's Renal Hypoperfusion Lecture

Question: Tom is inspecting a wound on his leg that he sustained whilst out running in the park 3 days ago. Which of the following processes is most likely occurring in his wound?
Explanation:
B & C = after day 7 

D & E= 6 weeks to 1 year 

A = 3 days ago, therefore the wound would still be in the inflammatory phase which typically lasts around 5 days. Neutrophils migrate into the wound, growth factors are released and fibroblasts undergo replication.

Question: What are majority of tumours derived from?
Explanation: Most tumours are derived from stem cells, stems cells divide forming a daughter cell - one cell forming a more specialised cell

Question: What is easier to do?
Explanation:
It is much easier to sequence DNA than synthesise it.

Genomics of cancer lecture

Question: What percentage of cancers are inherited?
Explanation: cancer genetics lecture, case 16

Question:
Mrs James, a 65 year old woman comes into hospital presenting with vertigo, nystagmus, ataxia, vomiting and dysphagia. She is diagnosed with lateral medullary syndrome. 

 

This is an infarct of what vessel?
Explanation:
this is an infarct at the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. 

 

PCA infarct presents with acute vision loss, confusion and a new posterior cerebral headache. 

SCA infarct presents with unsteady gait, dysarthria and (sometimes) vertigo 

AICA infarct presents with vertigo and hearing loss 

MCA infarct presents with unilateral weakness, facial droop and speech deficits

Question: What type of DNA repair corrects interstrand breaks and double strand breaks?
OptionC: Homologous recombination and non homologous end joining
Explanation:
Homologous recombination is slower and more accurate 

Non homologous end joining is quicker but less accurate

Question: What fraction of cancers have a mutation in ras?
Explanation:
Summary 1 – Sustained proliferative signalling
- Cells normally only divide in response to external signals
- Cancer cells become independent of this control by mutating components of intracellular signalling pathways
- These can be receptors (eg EGFR), regulatory proteins (eg ras) or intracellular kinases (eg RAF)
– Referred to as oncogenes
– Ras is mutated in c. 1⁄4 of cancers

Question: What cardiac pathology does this pressure volume loop show?
Explanation:
In aortic stenosis, the valve is calcified so the left ventricle has to generate a higher pressure to overcome the increased resistance.

I'm not sure why volume changes so please leave any suggestions :)

 

Case 12 -Pressure volume loop tutorial

Question: Which of the following is the most likely cause for hyperthyroidism?
Explanation:
Grave's disease is most common cause of hyperthyroidism

Hashimoto's disease is most common cause of hypothyroidism

All others listed are other causes of hyperthyroidism

Question: Mrs Khan was on Haloperidol and started getting symptoms of dystonia, Parkinsonism, tardive dyskinesia and tremors. Her GP changed her medication to Onlazopine. What was causing these symptoms?
Explanation:
psychomotor retardation is due to reduced movement in the nigrostriatal pathway

EPSE correct due to dopamine blockade of nigrostriatal input 

lack of exercise is wrong

H1 antagonism would cause sedation 

alpha 1 adrenorecptor blockade causes postural hypotension

Question: You are a second year student, currently crying over not understanding a lecture on blood volumes and cardiac output graph changes (you know which one I'm talking about) You are discussing your understanding with another student who asks you what the response would be if someone was to have had a traumatic head injury with severe blood loss. You reply with...
OptionA: Barorecpetors detect a change in the stretch of the blood vessels. This causes smooth muscle contraction which decreases the diameter of the blood vessels returning the blood pressure and cardiac output to setpoint - in response to the blood loss
OptionB: The reduction in blood volume triggers activation of ryanodine receptors causing an increase in CICR. This causes an influx of Ca into cardiomyocytes causing an increase in actin myosin crossbridge formation thus increasing contractility in response to blood loss
OptionC: Sympathetic innervation acts as a positive inotrope causing vasoconstriction. This increases the peripheral vascular resistance increasing contractility so more blood is pumped out of the heart to respond to the blood loss.
OptionD: Proprioceptors detect a change in heart rate and blood pressure. This causes signalling to the hypothalamus to increase sympathetic innervation to the heart in order to increase heart rate
Explanation:
The correct answer is C.

1) A fall in blood volume causes the venous blood curve to shift to the left. This is due to sympathetic innervation acting as a positive inotrope.

2) Sympathetic innervation causes vasoconstriction of blood vessels. This will increase peripheral vascular resistance.

3) This causes an increase in contractility of the heart so more blood is pumped out.

4) If more blood is being pumped out then the right arterial pressure will decrease (this is the x axis on the graph which is why it moves left)

5) In order to increase venous return there is an increase in EPO which increases RBC production increasing blood volume - I hope this makes some sense

 

Please use this link to see a diagram:

https://www.google.com/search?q=venous+return+right+atrial+pressure+graph&rlz=1C1CHBF_en-GBGB760GB760&sxsrf=ALeKk00KD9jwAQqCRvgto1vwmDUeYyUPKg:1621779077095&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwim9Kzu_d_wAhVLA2MBHR6dDMsQ_AUoAXoECAEQAw&biw=1368&bih=802&dpr=2#imgrc=frFaW9gZQrq_SM

 

A - this is in fact the myogenic response to an increase in GFR. A rise in BP causes stretching of the afferent arteriole. To counteract this smooth muscle contracts returning the GFR back to normal.

B - I made this up 

D - Proprioceptors are found in the golgi tendon organs and respond to changes in movement to help reuglate breathing
Tags: Brain Injury, Cardiovascular System, Case 17, haematology

Question: A 24-year-old patient presents to the GP complaining of polydipsia, polyuria, and weight loss. You decide to take a random plasma glucose measurement. Which of the following values is required for a diagnosis of diabetes?
Explanation:
Refer to Case 11, Overview of diabetes lecture

 

A random plasma glucose of > 11.1 mmol/L is consistent with a diagnosis of diabetes. 

 

Other diagnostic values are: 

 

HbA1c > 6.5%

 

Or

 

Fasting plasma glucose > 7.0 mmol/L

Question: A patient is suspected to have Type 1 Diabetes. Although they are asymptomatic, their blood work reveals dysglycaemia. How would you stage this diabetes?
Explanation:
Only 3 stages exist for T1D.

 

Stage 1 = asymptomatic, normoglycaemia 

 

Stage 2 = asymptomatic, dysglycaemia

 

Stage 3 = symptomatic, dysglycaemia

Question: Mr Jones is a 35 year old patient with IBD. Which of his following symptoms is an extra-intestinal manifestation that is NOT related to the disease activity?
Explanation: All of these symptoms except liver disease are related to the disease activity

Question: During PCI, access to the femoral artery is required. What is the anatomical landmark for the femoral artery?
OptionA: Midway between ASIS and the pubic tubercle
OptionB: 3 cm inferior to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
OptionE: Two thirds of way between ASIS and pubic tubercle
Explanation:
A = inguinal ligament midpoint 

C = correct

Question: What should be used when investigating toxic megacolon?
Explanation: This question was just meant to highlight the importance of both barium enema and colonscopy being contraindicated in toxic megacolon

Question:
You are a GP when Sam, a 50 year old man, comes in to see you. On first impression he looks jaundiced and complains of symptoms of fever, diarrhoea, muscle aches and abdominal pain. He also mentions he's recently returned from Thailand. You send off his bloods for serology and the results are as follows: 

 

HbsAg - positive

IgM Anti-Hbc - positive

Anti-Hbs - negative

 

What do these results show?
OptionB: Immunity due to previous hepatitis B infection
Explanation:
These results show that Sam is acutely infected with hepatitis B. 

 

HbsAg shows that a person is INFECTED at that point in time. This can be acute or chronic. 

 

Anti-Hbc is a marker of infection at some unidentified point in life (could be right now). Anti-Hbc is only present in people who have been naturally exposed to the virus (because the vaccine contains the surface antigen), showing that this is a natural infection. IgM is always the first antibody produced and so this is the key clue showing that the patient is acutely infected. 

 

Anti-Hbs shows immunity through either natural infection or vaccination.

Question: Which of the following signs/symptoms is most likely to be associated with a lacunar stroke?
Explanation:
B - Weber's syndrome 

C - Wallenburg syndrome 

D - Lateral pontine syndrome 

E - retinal artery occlusion 

 

Lacunar strokes are likely to present with isolated hemiparesis, hemisensory loss or hemiparesis with limb weakness. They are strongly associated with hypertension.

Question: A young girl and her mum present to A&E. The mother is clearly distressed and explains that her daughter, Maisy, 11, accidentally spilled boiling hot water from the kettle on to her forearm and has sustained a significant burn. You examine Maisy's burn. It is white, and Maisy states that it doesn't hurt her. What would expect in this scenario?
OptionA: This is a superficial burn which has a good prognosis, hence why there is no pain
OptionB: This is a superficial burn and therefore no blood vessels are affected, hence why it is white
OptionC: This is a partial thickness burn, and there is no pain because the sensory nerves have not been stimulated
OptionD: This is a full thickness burn and the sensory neurones have been damaged
OptionE: This is a full thickness burn and she does not feel pain because she has a high pain threshold
Explanation: No colour and no pain = full thickness, poor prognosis and a possible medical emergency.

Question: Mrs Jones arrives via ambulance in A&E. You are informed that she is having an NSTEMI causing her severe chest pain. You decide to prescribe glyceryl trinitrate, but what is the best mode of administration in this scenario?
Explanation: GTN is delivered via a sub-lingual spray in most cases. This allows it to avoid first-pass metabolism in the liver, where it would usually be deactivated. IV is also a possibility here, however in an urgent emergency setting, sub-lingual is more convenient and is therefore favoured.

Question: A patient presents to A&E with increasing symptoms of numbness, pins and needles and muscle weakness. She is diagnosed with Guillian-Barre syndrome. Which cell type if affected in GBS?
Explanation:
A = oligodendrocytes are the cell type affected in MS 

C = schwann cells produce myelin in PNS and are affected in GBS

Question: Interaction between a T follicular helper cell and a B cell has two important consequences. What are these?
Explanation:
Interaction between CD40L on a Tfh and CD40 on a B cell results in the activation of Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID). This catalyses somatic hypermutation (which leads to affinity maturation) and isotype switching. 

 

Side note: somatic recombination is gene rearrangement that occurs in lymphocyte development (before antigen presentation) that allows for a wide range of antibodies, with different antigen specificities, to be produced.

Question: What is another name for a non sense mutation?
Explanation: A nonsense mutation can be referred to as a stop gain mutation which truncates the protein.

Question: Candace is given morphine following surgery and develops constipation as an ADR. What is the mechanism for this?
OptionA: Agonism of mu-opioid receptors decreasing gut motility
OptionB: Agonism of delta-opioid receptors decreasing gut motility
OptionC: Antagonism of mu-opioid receptors decreasing gut motility
OptionE: Agonsim of norepinephrine receptors stimulating the sympathetic nervous system and decreasing gastric motility
Explanation: Morphine and other opioid analgaesics target the mu-opioid receptors in the CNS and PNS and cause analgaesia, miosis and decreased gut motility, hence why they cause constipation.

Question: What class of antibiotic can cause tendonitis?
Explanation: Quinolones eg. levoflaxcin can cause tendonitis and QT elongation

Question: An 8 year old boy is treated with a cephalosporin antibiotic for meningitis. What is the MoA?
Explanation: Cephalosporins - inhibits cell wall formation

Question:
Harry is a 16 year old boy who has been suffering from a fever and headache for the past couple of days. He presents to A & E after having a seizure with weakness at school that day.

 

After running some tests, as well as sending him for a non-contrast CT, the doctor diagnoses him with subdural empyema. The doctor is talking to Harry's aunt who brought him into the hospital to try and find out the source of the infection. She recalled he was feeling a bit ill a few weeks ago but cannot remember what he had. 

 

What is the most common cause of inter-cranial infections?
OptionE: Haematogenous spread e.g., lung infections, UTI, endocarditis
Explanation:
Inter-cranial infections are most common in children and young adults. The main types are:

  • Intracerebral abscess
  • Subdural/extradural empyema (collections of pus)

The sources are commonly:

  • Paranasal sinus infections – most common
  • Dental abscess
  • Middle ear and mastoid infections
  • Haematogenous spread – lung infections, UTI, endocarditis
  • Penetrating head trauma
  • Post-op

 

The common organisms responsible are:

  • Staph. Aureus (from trauma and post op)
  • Aerobic/anaerobic streptococci (from middle ear infections)

These patients often go septic, so they are taken too surgery and washed out.

Inflammatory markers are usually up (CRP, WCC), a blood culture must also be taken for C&S.

Post op give the patient antibiotics for 6-12 weeks.

Question: If all cells can express MHC class 1, why can only CD cells activate a CD8+ T cell?
OptionA: Due to CD7 signal being present on CDC cell
OptionB: Due CD8+ cell releasing V2 a 'activate me signal'
OptionD: Due to MHC C1 and CD8+ interaction
OptionE: Due to CDC movement to lymph node via CC28
Explanation:
To activate a CD8+ T cell two signals are required:

1. interaction between CD8+ co receptor 

2. B7 from CDC and CD28 from t cell interaction 

- not all cells express B7 and therefore not all cells despite having capacity to express MHC complexes can activate a t cell
Tags: Immune Response, Case 9, Immune System, Immunology

Question:
A 50 year old man presents to the GP with a week history of fever, vomiting and abdominal pain. He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes. A urine dipstick test is done and reveals:
Glucose: normal
Bilirubin: negative
Ketones: negative
pH: 9
Blood: ca.25
Protein:negative
Nitrites: ++
Urobilinogen: normal
Leukocyte esterase: ca. 75
What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
Explanation:
Biliary obstruction - bilirubin negative and urobilinogen normal so can’t be obstruction 
Diabetes mellitus - glucose normal so cant be DM
Nephrotic syndrome - protein negative so cant be nephrotic syndrome 
Urethritis - blood present so cant be urethritis 

 

A urine pH of 8.5 or 9.0 is indicative of a urea-splitting organism, such as Proteus, Klebsiella, or Ureaplasma urealyticum; therefore, an asymptomatic patient with a high pH means UTI regardless of the other urine test results.

bacteria have an enzyme that converts nitrates into nitrites. This is why the presence of nitrites in your urine is an indicator that you may have a UTI

 

Nephrotic syndrome

Triad:
(1) Proteinuria (>3.5g per day)
(2) Hypoalbuminaemia
(3) Oedema (eyes, legs, ascites, pleural effusion)

Associated with hyperlipidaemia, reduced immunity (less protein so less immunoglobins) and hypercoagulation

Manifestation of glomerular disease

 

Causes:
- Adults – diabetic nephropathy, membranous GMN, focal segmental GMN
- Children – minimal change disease (treatment: steroids)

Question:
